European missionaries and others felt it was important to "civilize" the Native Americans and urged them to adopt European agricultural techniques and lifestyles.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">\n        <a href="#cite_note-107">\n         [99]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">\n        <a href="#cite_note-108">\n         [100]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1876" data-file-width="2500" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg/200px-Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg/300px-Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg/400px-Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg 2x" width="200"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Zoffany_Death_of_Captain_Cook.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <i>\n          Death of Captain Cook\n         </i>\n         by\n         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Johann_Zoffany" title="Johann Zoffany">\n          Johann Zoffany\n         </a>\n         (1795)\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Captain James Cook\'s last voyage included sailing along the coast of North America and Alaska searching for a\n       <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Passage" title="Northwest Passage">\n        Northwest Passage\n       </a>\n       for approximately nine months. He returned to the Hawaii to resupply, initially exploring the coasts of\n       <a href="/wiki/Maui" title="Maui">\n        Maui\n       </a>\n       and the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hawaii_Island" title="Hawaii Island">\n        big island\n       </a>\n       , trading with locals and then making anchor at\n       <a href="/wiki/Kealakekua_Bay" title="Kealakekua Bay">\n        Kealakekua Bay\n       </a>\n       in January 1779. When his ships and company left the islands, a ship\'s mast broke in bad weather, forcing them to return in mid-February. Cook would be killed days later.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Campbell2010_109-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Campbell2010-109">\n         [101]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">\n        <a href="#cite_note-113">\n         [fn 9]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">\n        <a href="#cite_note-123">\n         [fn 10]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span id="Independence_and_expansion_(1776\xe2\x80\x931865)">\n       </span>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_and_expansion_.281776.E2.80.931865.29">\n        Independence and expansion (1776\xe2\x80\x931865)\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Further information:\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">\n        American Revolutionary War\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">\n        United States Declaration of Independence\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">\n        American Revolution\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_the_United_States" title="Territorial evolution of the United States">\n        Territorial evolution of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Declaration_of_Independence_(1819),_by_John_Trumbull.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1969" data-file-width="2976" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Declaration_of_Independence_%281819%29%2C_by_John_Trumbull.jpg/220px-Declaration_of_Independence_%281819%29%2C_by_John_Trumbull.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Declaration_of_Independence_%281819%29%2C_by_John_Trumbull.jpg/330px-Declaration_of_Independence_%281819%29%2C_by_John_Trumbull.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Declaration_of_Independence_%281819%29%2C_by_John_Trumbull.jpg/440px-Declaration_of_Independence_%281819%29%2C_by_John_Trumbull.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Declaration_of_Independence_(1819),_by_John_Trumbull.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <i>\n          <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Independence_(Trumbull)" title="Declaration of Independence (Trumbull)">\n           Declaration of Independence\n          </a>\n         </i>\n         by\n         <a href="/wiki/John_Trumbull" title="John Trumbull">\n          John Trumbull\n         </a>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The American Revolutionary War was the first successful colonial war of independence against a European power. Americans had developed an ideology of "\n       <a href="/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States" title="Republicanism in the United States">\n        republicanism\n       </a>\n       " asserting that government rested on the will of the people as expressed in their local legislatures. They demanded their\n       <a href="/wiki/Rights_of_Englishmen" title="Rights of Englishmen">\n        rights as Englishmen\n       </a>\n       and "no taxation without representation". The British insisted on administering the empire through Parliament, and\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">\n        the conflict\n       </a>\n       escalated into war.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Humphrey2003_124-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Humphrey2003-124">\n         [114]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Following the passage of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Lee_Resolution" title="Lee Resolution">\n        Lee Resolution\n       </a>\n       , on July 2, 1776, which was the actual vote for independence, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress" title="Second Continental Congress">\n        Second Continental Congress\n       </a>\n       adopted the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">\n        Declaration of Independence\n       </a>\n       on July 4, which proclaimed, in a long preamble, that humanity is created equal in their unalienable rights and that those rights were not being protected by\n       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">\n        Great Britain\n       </a>\n       , and declared, in the words of the resolution, that the\n       <a href="/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies" title="Thirteen Colonies">\n        Thirteen Colonies\n       </a>\n       were independent states and had no allegiance to the British crown in the United States. The fourth day of July is celebrated annually as\n       <a href="/wiki/Independence_Day_(United_States)" title="Independence Day (United States)">\n        Independence Day\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-YoungNash2011_125-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-YoungNash2011-125">\n         [115]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The Second Continental Congress declared on September 9 "where, heretofore, the words \'United Colonies\' have been used, the stile be altered for the future to the \'United States\' ".\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel1920323-324_126-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel1920323-324-126">\n         [116]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 1777, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation" title="Articles of Confederation">\n        Articles of Confederation\n       </a>\n       established a weak government that operated until 1789.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-YoungNash2011_125-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-YoungNash2011-125">\n         [115]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Britain recognized the independence of the United States following their\n       <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Yorktown" title="Siege of Yorktown">\n        defeat at Yorktown\n       </a>\n       in 1781.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">\n        <a href="#cite_note-127">\n         [117]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In the\n       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1783)" title="Treaty of Paris (1783)">\n        peace treaty of 1783\n       </a>\n       , American sovereignty was recognized from the Atlantic coast west to the Mississippi River. Nationalists led the\n       <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Convention_(United_States)" title="Constitutional Convention (United States)">\n        Philadelphia Convention\n       </a>\n       of 1787 in writing the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" title="United States Constitution">\n        United States Constitution\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ratification_of_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Ratification of the United States Constitution">\n        ratified\n       </a>\n       in state conventions in 1788. The federal government was reorganized into three branches, on the principle of creating salutary checks and balances, in 1789. George Washington, who had led the revolutionary army to victory, was the first\n       <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">\n        president\n       </a>\n       elected under the new constitution. The\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights" title="United States Bill of Rights">\n        Bill of Rights\n       </a>\n       , forbidding federal restriction of\n       <a href="/wiki/Natural_and_legal_rights" title="Natural and legal rights">\n        personal freedoms\n       </a>\n       and guaranteeing a range of legal protections, was adopted in 1791.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BoyerJr.2007_128-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-BoyerJr.2007-128">\n         [118]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Although the federal government criminalized the international slave trade in 1808, after 1820, cultivation of the highly profitable cotton crop exploded in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Deep_South" title="Deep South">\n        Deep South\n       </a>\n       , and along with it, the slave population.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cogliano2008_129-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Cogliano2008-129">\n         [119]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">\n        <a href="#cite_note-130">\n         [120]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">\n        <a href="#cite_note-131">\n         [121]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Second_Great_Awakening" title="Second Great Awakening">\n        Second Great Awakening\n       </a>\n       , especially 1800\xe2\x80\x931840, converted millions to\n       <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">\n        evangelical\n       </a>\n       Protestantism. In the North, it energized multiple social reform movements, including\n       <a href="/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States" title="Abolitionism in the United States">\n        abolitionism\n       </a>\n       ;\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Clark2012iu_132-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Clark2012iu-132">\n         [122]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       in the South, Methodists and Baptists proselytized among slave populations.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">\n        <a href="#cite_note-133">\n         [123]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Americans\' eagerness to\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_territorial_acquisitions" title="United States territorial acquisitions">\n        expand westward\n       </a>\n       prompted a long series of\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Indian_Wars" title="American Indian Wars">\n        American Indian Wars\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BillingtonRidge2001j_134-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-BillingtonRidge2001j-134">\n         [124]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase" title="Louisiana Purchase">\n        Louisiana Purchase\n       </a>\n       of French-claimed territory in 1803 almost doubled the nation\'s area.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">\n        <a href="#cite_note-135">\n         [125]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/War_of_1812" title="War of 1812">\n        War of 1812\n       </a>\n       , declared against Britain over various grievances and fought to a draw, strengthened U.S. nationalism.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wait1999_136-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Wait1999-136">\n         [126]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       A series of military incursions into Florida led\n       <a href="/wiki/Adams%E2%80%93On%C3%ADs_Treaty" title="Adams\xe2\x80\x93On\xc3\xads Treaty">\n        Spain to cede\n       </a>\n       it and other Gulf Coast territory in 1819.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KloseJones1994_137-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-KloseJones1994-137">\n         [127]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Expansion was aided by\n       <a href="/wiki/Steam_engine" title="Steam engine">\n        steam power\n       </a>\n       , when\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Steamboats" title="Steamboats">\n        steamboats\n       </a>\n       began traveling along America\'s large water systems, which were connected by new\n       <a href="/wiki/Canal" title="Canal">\n        canals\n       </a>\n       , such as the\n       <a href="/wiki/Erie_Canal" title="Erie Canal">\n        Erie\n       </a>\n       and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Illinois_and_Michigan_Canal" title="Illinois and Michigan Canal">\n        I&amp;M\n       </a>\n       ; then, even faster railroads began their stretch across the nation\'s land.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">\n        <a href="#cite_note-138">\n         [128]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       From 1820 to 1850,\n       <a href="/wiki/Jacksonian_democracy" title="Jacksonian democracy">\n        Jacksonian democracy\n       </a>\n       began a set of reforms which included wider white male suffrage; it led to the rise of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Second_Party_System" title="Second Party System">\n        Second Party System\n       </a>\n       of Democrats and Whigs as the dominant parties from 1828 to 1854. The\n       <a href="/wiki/Trail_of_Tears" title="Trail of Tears">\n        Trail of Tears\n       </a>\n       in the 1830s exemplified the\n       <a href="/wiki/Indian_Removal_Act" title="Indian Removal Act">\n        Indian removal policy\n       </a>\n       that resettled Indians into the west on\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_reservations" title="Indian reservations">\n        Indian reservations\n       </a>\n       . The U.S. annexed the\n       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Texas" title="Republic of Texas">\n        Republic of Texas\n       </a>\n       in 1845 during a period of expansionist\n       <a href="/wiki/Manifest_destiny" title="Manifest destiny">\n        Manifest destiny\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morrison1999_139-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Morrison1999-139">\n         [129]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The 1846\n       <a href="/wiki/Oregon_Treaty" title="Oregon Treaty">\n        Oregon Treaty\n       </a>\n       with Britain led to U.S. control of the present-day\n       <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_United_States" title="Northwestern United States">\n        American Northwest\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kemp2010_140-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Kemp2010-140">\n         [130]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Victory in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War" title="Mexican\xe2\x80\x93American War">\n        Mexican\xe2\x80\x93American War\n       </a>\n       resulted in the 1848\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Cession" title="Mexican Cession">\n        Mexican Cession\n       </a>\n       of California and much of the present-day American Southwest.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McIlwraithMuller2001_141-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-McIlwraithMuller2001-141">\n         [131]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/California_Gold_Rush" title="California Gold Rush">\n        California Gold Rush\n       </a>\n       of 1848\xe2\x80\x9349 spurred western migration and the creation of additional western states.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rawls1999_142-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Rawls1999-142">\n         [132]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       After the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">\n        American Civil War\n       </a>\n       , new transcontinental\n       <a href="/wiki/Rail_transportation_in_the_United_States#History" title="Rail transportation in the United States">\n        railways\n       </a>\n       made relocation easier for settlers, expanded internal trade and increased conflicts with Native Americans.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Black2011kj_143-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Black2011kj-143">\n         [133]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Over a half-century, the loss of the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_bison" title="American bison">\n        American bison\n       </a>\n       (sometimes called "buffalo") was an existential blow to many\n       <a href="/wiki/Plains_Indians" title="Plains Indians">\n        Plains Indians\n       </a>\n       cultures.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wishart2004_144-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Wishart2004-144">\n         [134]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 1869, a new\n       <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Ulysses_S._Grant#Indian_affairs_and_human_rights" title="Presidency of Ulysses S. Grant">\n        Peace Policy\n       </a>\n       sought to protect Native-Americans from abuses, avoid further war, and secure their eventual U.S. citizenship, although conflicts, including several of the largest Indian Wars, continued throughout the West into the 1900s.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smith_pp525-526_145-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Smith_pp525-526-145">\n         [135]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg/220px-Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg/330px-Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg/440px-Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The\n         <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">\n          Statue of Liberty\n         </a>\n         in\n         <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">\n          New York City\n         </a>\n         , dedicated in 1886, is a symbol of the United States as well as its ideals of freedom, democracy and opportunity.\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">\n          <a href="#cite_note-146">\n           [136]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_War_and_Reconstruction_Era">\n        Civil War and Reconstruction Era\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Further information:\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">\n        American Civil War\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Reconstruction_Era" title="Reconstruction Era">\n        Reconstruction Era\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Thure_de_Thulstrup_-_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_(cropped).jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="6202" data-file-width="8859" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Thure_de_Thulstrup_-_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Thure_de_Thulstrup_-_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Thure_de_Thulstrup_-_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Thure_de_Thulstrup_-_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Thure_de_Thulstrup_-_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Thure_de_Thulstrup_-_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Thure_de_Thulstrup_-_L._Prang_and_Co._-_Battle_of_Gettysburg_-_Restoration_by_Adam_Cuerden_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <i>\n          The\n          <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gettysburg" title="Battle of Gettysburg">\n           Battle of Gettysburg\n          </a>\n         </i>\n         by\n         <a href="/wiki/Thure_de_Thulstrup" title="Thure de Thulstrup">\n          Thure de Thulstrup\n         </a>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Differences of opinion over social order between northern and southern states in early United States society, particularly regarding\n       <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States" title="Slavery in the United States">\n        the slavery\n       </a>\n       of\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Africans" title="Africans">\n        Africans\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/African_Americans" title="African Americans">\n        African Americans\n       </a>\n       , ultimately led to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Origins_of_the_American_Civil_War" title="Origins of the American Civil War">\n        American Civil War\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">\n        <a href="#cite_note-147">\n         [137]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Initially, states entering the Union alternated between\n       <a href="/wiki/Slave_states_and_free_states" title="Slave states and free states">\n        slave and free states\n       </a>\n       , keeping a sectional balance in the Senate, while free states outstripped slave states in population and in the House of Representatives. But with additional western territory and more free-soil states, tensions between slave and free states mounted with arguments over federalism and disposition of the territories, whether and how to expand or restrict slavery.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O.27Brien2002qs_148-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-O.27Brien2002qs-148">\n         [138]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       With the 1860 election of\n       <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">\n        Abraham Lincoln\n       </a>\n       , the first president from the largely anti-slavery\n       <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">\n        Republican Party\n       </a>\n       , conventions in thirteen slave states ultimately declared secession and formed the\n       <a href="/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America" title="Confederate States of America">\n        Confederate States of America\n       </a>\n       , while the federal government maintained that secession was illegal.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O.27Brien2002qs_148-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-O.27Brien2002qs-148">\n         [138]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The ensuing war was at first for Union, then after 1863 as casualties mounted and Lincoln delivered his\n       <a href="/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation" title="Emancipation Proclamation">\n        Emancipation Proclamation\n       </a>\n       , a second war aim became abolition of slavery. The war remains the deadliest military conflict in American history, resulting in the deaths of approximately 618,000 soldiers as well as many civilians.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">\n        <a href="#cite_note-149">\n         [139]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Following the\n       <a href="/wiki/Union_(American_Civil_War)" title="Union (American Civil War)">\n        Union\n       </a>\n       victory in 1865,\n       <a href="/wiki/Reconstruction_Amendments" title="Reconstruction Amendments">\n        three amendments\n       </a>\n       were added to the U.S. Constitution: the\n       <a href="/wiki/Thirteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution">\n        Thirteenth Amendment\n       </a>\n       prohibited slavery, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution">\n        Fourteenth Amendment\n       </a>\n       provided citizenship to the nearly four million\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">\n        African Americans\n       </a>\n       who had been slaves,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">\n        <a href="#cite_note-150">\n         [140]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Fifteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution">\n        Fifteenth Amendment\n       </a>\n       ensured that they had the right to vote. The war and its resolution led to a substantial increase in\n       <a href="/wiki/Federalism_in_the_United_States" title="Federalism in the United States">\n        federal power\n       </a>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">\n        <a href="#cite_note-151">\n         [141]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       aimed at reintegrating and rebuilding the Southern states while ensuring the rights of the newly freed slaves.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Southern white conservatives, calling themselves "\n       <a href="/wiki/Redeemers" title="Redeemers">\n        Redeemers\n       </a>\n       " took control after the end of Reconstruction. By the 1890\xe2\x80\x931910 period\n       <a href="/wiki/Jim_Crow_laws" title="Jim Crow laws">\n        Jim Crow laws\n       </a>\n       <a href="/wiki/Disenfranchisement_after_the_Reconstruction_Era" title="Disenfranchisement after the Reconstruction Era">\n        disenfranchised\n       </a>\n       most blacks and some poor whites. Blacks faced\n       <a href="/wiki/Racial_segregation_in_the_United_States" title="Racial segregation in the United States">\n        racial segregation\n       </a>\n       , especially in the South.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">\n        <a href="#cite_note-152">\n         [142]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Racial minorities occasionally experienced\n       <a href="/wiki/Lynching_in_the_United_States" title="Lynching in the United States">\n        vigilante violence\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">\n        <a href="#cite_note-153">\n         [143]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span id="Further_immigration,_expansion,_and_industrialization">\n       </span>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Further_immigration.2C_expansion.2C_and_industrialization">\n        Further immigration, expansion, and industrialization\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main articles:\n       <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_the_United_States" title="Economic history of the United States">\n        Economic history of the United States\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Technological_and_industrial_history_of_the_United_States" title="Technological and industrial history of the United States">\n        Technological and industrial history of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ellis_island_1902.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="812" data-file-width="1185" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Ellis_island_1902.jpg/220px-Ellis_island_1902.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Ellis_island_1902.jpg/330px-Ellis_island_1902.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Ellis_island_1902.jpg/440px-Ellis_island_1902.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ellis_island_1902.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Island" title="Ellis Island">\n          Ellis Island\n         </a>\n         , in New York City, was a major gateway for European\n         <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States" title="Immigration to the United States">\n          immigration\n         </a>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PriceBenton-Short2008_154-0">\n          <a href="#cite_note-PriceBenton-Short2008-154">\n           [144]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       In the North, urbanization and an unprecedented\n       <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States#History" title="Immigration to the United States">\n        influx of immigrants\n       </a>\n       from\n       <a href="/wiki/Southern_Europe" title="Southern Europe">\n        Southern\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">\n        Eastern Europe\n       </a>\n       supplied a surplus of labor for the country\'s industrialization and transformed its culture.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Powell2009qwet_155-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Powell2009qwet-155">\n         [145]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       National infrastructure including\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Transcontinental_Telegraph" title="First Transcontinental Telegraph">\n        telegraph\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/First_Transcontinental_Railroad" title="First Transcontinental Railroad">\n        transcontinental railroads\n       </a>\n       spurred economic growth and greater settlement and development of the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_frontier" title="American frontier">\n        American Old West\n       </a>\n       . The later invention of\n       <a href="/wiki/Incandescent_light_bulb" title="Incandescent light bulb">\n        electric light\n       </a>\n       and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Telephone" title="Telephone">\n        telephone\n       </a>\n       would also affect communication and urban life.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">\n        <a href="#cite_note-156">\n         [146]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tleft">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:American_Empire1.PNG">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="2753" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/American_Empire1.PNG/250px-American_Empire1.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/American_Empire1.PNG/375px-American_Empire1.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/American_Empire1.PNG/500px-American_Empire1.PNG 2x" width="250"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:American_Empire1.PNG" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         United States and its territories at their greatest extent from 1898 to 1902\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The end of the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Indian_Wars" title="American Indian Wars">\n        Indian Wars\n       </a>\n       further expanded acreage under mechanical cultivation, increasing surpluses for international markets.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">\n        <a href="#cite_note-157">\n         [147]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Mainland expansion was completed by the\n       <a href="/wiki/Alaska_Purchase" title="Alaska Purchase">\n        purchase of Alaska\n       </a>\n       from\n       <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">\n        Russia\n       </a>\n       in 1867.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">\n        <a href="#cite_note-158">\n         [148]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 1893, pro-American elements in Hawaii\n       <a href="/wiki/Overthrow_of_the_Kingdom_of_Hawaii" title="Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii">\n        overthrew\n       </a>\n       the\n       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hawaii" title="Kingdom of Hawaii">\n        monarchy\n       </a>\n       and formed the\n       <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Hawaii" title="Republic of Hawaii">\n        Republic of Hawaii\n       </a>\n       , which the U.S.\n       <a href="/wiki/Territory_of_Hawaii" title="Territory of Hawaii">\n        annexed\n       </a>\n       in 1898.\n       <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico" title="Puerto Rico">\n        Puerto Rico\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">\n        Guam\n       </a>\n       , and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">\n        Philippines\n       </a>\n       were ceded by Spain in the same year, following the\n       <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish\xe2\x80\x93American War">\n        Spanish\xe2\x80\x93American War\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">\n        <a href="#cite_note-159">\n         [149]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Gilded_Age" title="Gilded Age">\n        Rapid economic development\n       </a>\n       during the late 19th and early 20th centuries fostered the rise of many prominent industrialists.\n       <a href="/wiki/Business_magnate" title="Business magnate">\n        Tycoons\n       </a>\n       like\n       <a href="/wiki/Cornelius_Vanderbilt" title="Cornelius Vanderbilt">\n        Cornelius Vanderbilt\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/John_D._Rockefeller" title="John D. Rockefeller">\n        John D. Rockefeller\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie" title="Andrew Carnegie">\n        Andrew Carnegie\n       </a>\n       led the nation\'s progress in\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Railways" title="Railways">\n        railroad\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_industry" title="Petroleum industry">\n        petroleum\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_the_steel_industry" title="History of the steel industry">\n        steel\n       </a>\n       industries. Banking became a major part of the economy, with\n       <a href="/wiki/J._P._Morgan" title="J. P. Morgan">\n        J. P. Morgan\n       </a>\n       playing a notable role.\n       <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Edison" title="Thomas Edison">\n        Edison\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Tesla" title="Nikola Tesla">\n        Tesla\n       </a>\n       undertook the widespread distribution of electricity to industry, homes, and for street lighting.\n       <a href="/wiki/Henry_Ford" title="Henry Ford">\n        Henry Ford\n       </a>\n       revolutionized the\n       <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry" title="Automotive industry">\n        automotive industry\n       </a>\n       . The American economy boomed, becoming the world\'s largest, and the United States achieved\n       <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">\n        great power\n       </a>\n       status.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">\n        <a href="#cite_note-160">\n         [150]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       These dramatic changes were accompanied by social unrest and the rise of\n       <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Party_(United_States)" title="People\'s Party (United States)">\n        populist\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_socialist_movement_in_the_United_States" title="History of the socialist movement in the United States">\n        socialist\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Anarchism_in_the_United_States" title="Anarchism in the United States">\n        anarchist\n       </a>\n       movements.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">\n        <a href="#cite_note-161">\n         [151]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       This period eventually ended with the advent of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Progressive_Era" title="Progressive Era">\n        Progressive Era\n       </a>\n       , which saw significant reforms in many societal areas, including\n       <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage" title="Women\'s suffrage">\n        women\'s suffrage\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States" title="Prohibition in the United States">\n        alcohol prohibition\n       </a>\n       , regulation of consumer goods, greater\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_antitrust_law" title="United States antitrust law">\n        antitrust measures\n       </a>\n       to ensure competition and attention to worker conditions.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">\n        <a href="#cite_note-162">\n         [152]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">\n        <a href="#cite_note-163">\n         [153]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">\n        <a href="#cite_note-164">\n         [154]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span id="World_War_I,_Great_Depression,_and_World_War_II">\n       </span>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_I.2C_Great_Depression.2C_and_World_War_II">\n        World War I, Great Depression, and World War II\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Further information:\n       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">\n        World War I\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">\n        Great Depression\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">\n        World War II\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Crowd_outside_nyse.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="349" data-file-width="251" height="306" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Crowd_outside_nyse.jpg/220px-Crowd_outside_nyse.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e1/Crowd_outside_nyse.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Crowd_outside_nyse.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Crowd gathering on\n         <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">\n          Wall Street\n         </a>\n         after the 1929 crash\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The United States remained neutral from the outbreak of\n       <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">\n        World War I\n       </a>\n       , in 1914, until 1917 when it joined the war as an "associated power", alongside the formal\n       <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">\n        Allies of World War I\n       </a>\n       , helping to turn the tide against the\n       <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">\n        Central Powers\n       </a>\n       . In 1919, President\n       <a href="/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson" title="Woodrow Wilson">\n        Woodrow Wilson\n       </a>\n       took a leading diplomatic role at the\n       <a href="/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919" title="Paris Peace Conference, 1919">\n        Paris Peace Conference\n       </a>\n       and advocated strongly for the U.S. to join the\n       <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">\n        League of Nations\n       </a>\n       . However, the Senate refused to approve this, and did not ratify the\n       <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles" title="Treaty of Versailles">\n        Treaty of Versailles\n       </a>\n       that established the League of Nations.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated418_165-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated418-165">\n         [155]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In 1920, the women\'s rights movement won passage of a\n       <a href="/wiki/Nineteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution">\n        constitutional amendment\n       </a>\n       granting\n       <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_the_United_States" title="Women\'s suffrage in the United States">\n        women\'s suffrage\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-voris_166-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-voris-166">\n         [156]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The 1920s and 1930s saw the rise of\n       <a href="/wiki/Radio" title="Radio">\n        radio\n       </a>\n       for\n       <a href="/wiki/Mass_communication" title="Mass communication">\n        mass communication\n       </a>\n       and the invention of early\n       <a href="/wiki/Television" title="Television">\n        television\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">\n        <a href="#cite_note-167">\n         [157]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The prosperity of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Roaring_Twenties" title="Roaring Twenties">\n        Roaring Twenties\n       </a>\n       ended with the\n       <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929" title="Wall Street Crash of 1929">\n        Wall Street Crash of 1929\n       </a>\n       and the onset of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_States" title="Great Depression in the United States">\n        Great Depression\n       </a>\n       . After his election as president in 1932,\n       <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">\n        Franklin D. Roosevelt\n       </a>\n       responded with the\n       <a href="/wiki/New_Deal" title="New Deal">\n        New Deal\n       </a>\n       , which included the establishment of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Social_Security_(United_States)" title="Social Security (United States)">\n        Social Security\n       </a>\n       system.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">\n        <a href="#cite_note-168">\n         [158]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American)" title="Great Migration (African American)">\n        Great Migration\n       </a>\n       of millions of African Americans out of the American South began before World War I and extended through the 1960s;\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">\n        <a href="#cite_note-169">\n         [159]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       whereas the\n       <a href="/wiki/Dust_Bowl" title="Dust Bowl">\n        Dust Bowl\n       </a>\n       of the mid-1930s impoverished many farming communities and spurred a new wave of western migration.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">\n        <a href="#cite_note-170">\n         [160]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       At first effectively neutral during\n       <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_the_United_States_during_World_War_II" title="Military history of the United States during World War II">\n        World War II\n       </a>\n       while Germany conquered much of continental Europe, the United States began supplying material to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">\n        Allies\n       </a>\n       in March 1941 through the\n       <a href="/wiki/Lend-Lease" title="Lend-Lease">\n        Lend-Lease\n       </a>\n       program. On December 7, 1941, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">\n        Empire of Japan\n       </a>\n       launched a surprise\n       <a href="/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor" title="Attack on Pearl Harbor">\n        attack on Pearl Harbor\n       </a>\n       , prompting the United States to join the Allies against the\n       <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">\n        Axis powers\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pearl_Harbor_171-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Pearl_Harbor-171">\n         [161]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       During the war, the United States was referred as one of the "\n       <a href="/wiki/Four_Policemen" title="Four Policemen">\n        Four Policemen\n       </a>\n       "\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">\n        <a href="#cite_note-172">\n         [162]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       of Allies power who met to plan the postwar world, along with Britain, the Soviet Union and China.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoopesBrinkley1997100_173-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoopesBrinkley1997100-173">\n         [163]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaddis197225_174-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaddis197225-174">\n         [164]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Though the nation lost more than 400,000 soldiers,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">\n        <a href="#cite_note-175">\n         [165]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       it emerged\n       <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties#Human_losses_by_country" title="World War II casualties">\n        relatively undamaged\n       </a>\n       from the war with even greater economic and military influence.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">\n        <a href="#cite_note-176">\n         [166]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The United States played a leading role in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Bretton_Woods_Conference" title="Bretton Woods Conference">\n        Bretton Woods\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Yalta_Conference" title="Yalta Conference">\n        Yalta\n       </a>\n       conferences with the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and other Allies, which signed agreements on new international financial institutions and Europe\'s postwar reorganization. As an\n       <a href="/wiki/Victory_in_Europe_Day" title="Victory in Europe Day">\n        Allied victory was won in Europe\n       </a>\n       , a 1945\n       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Conference_on_International_Organization" title="United Nations Conference on International Organization">\n        international conference\n       </a>\n       held in\n       <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">\n        San Francisco\n       </a>\n       produced the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Charter" title="United Nations Charter">\n        United Nations Charter\n       </a>\n       , which became active after the war.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">\n        <a href="#cite_note-177">\n         [167]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The United States developed the\n       <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Project" title="Manhattan Project">\n        first nuclear weapons\n       </a>\n       and used them on Japan\n       <a href="/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki" title="Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki">\n        in the cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki\n       </a>\n       ; causing the Japanese to\n       <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">\n        surrender\n       </a>\n       on September 2, ending World War II.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">\n        <a href="#cite_note-178">\n         [168]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">\n        <a href="#cite_note-179">\n         [169]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Parades and celebrations followed in what is known as\n       <a href="/wiki/Victory_Day_(United_States)" title="Victory Day (United States)">\n        Victory Day\n       </a>\n       , or V-J Day.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">\n        <a href="#cite_note-180">\n         [170]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cold_War_and_civil_rights_era">\n        Cold War and civil rights era\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main articles:\n       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1945%E2%80%9364)" title="History of the United States (1945\xe2\x80\x9364)">\n        History of the United States (1945\xe2\x80\x9364)\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1964%E2%80%9380)" title="History of the United States (1964\xe2\x80\x9380)">\n        History of the United States (1964\xe2\x80\x9380)\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1980%E2%80%9391)" title="History of the United States (1980\xe2\x80\x9391)">\n        History of the United States (1980\xe2\x80\x9391)\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Further information:\n       <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">\n        Cold War\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_Rights_Movement" title="Civil Rights Movement">\n        Civil Rights Movement\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/War_on_Poverty" title="War on Poverty">\n        War on Poverty\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">\n        Space Race\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Reaganomics" title="Reaganomics">\n        Reaganomics\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ReaganBerlinWall.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2009" data-file-width="2846" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/ReaganBerlinWall.jpg/220px-ReaganBerlinWall.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/ReaganBerlinWall.jpg/330px-ReaganBerlinWall.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/ReaganBerlinWall.jpg/440px-ReaganBerlinWall.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ReaganBerlinWall.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         U.S. President\n         <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">\n          Ronald Reagan\n         </a>\n         at his "\n         <a href="/wiki/Tear_down_this_wall!" title="Tear down this wall!">\n          Tear down this wall!\n         </a>\n         " speech in\n         <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">\n          Berlin\n         </a>\n         , Germany on June 12, 1987.\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-urlTear_Down_This_Wall_.7C_National_Archives_181-0">\n          <a href="#cite_note-urlTear_Down_This_Wall_.7C_National_Archives-181">\n           [171]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       After World War II the United States and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">\n        Soviet Union\n       </a>\n       jockeyed for power during what became known as the\n       <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">\n        Cold War\n       </a>\n       , driven by an ideological divide between\n       <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">\n        capitalism\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Communism" title="Communism">\n        communism\n       </a>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WaggAndrews2012_182-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-WaggAndrews2012-182">\n         [172]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and, according to the school of\n       <a href="/wiki/Geopolitics" title="Geopolitics">\n        geopolitics\n       </a>\n       , a divide between the maritime Atlantic and the continental Eurasian camps. They dominated the military affairs of\n       <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">\n        Europe\n       </a>\n       , with the U.S. and its\n       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">\n        NATO\n       </a>\n       allies on one side and the USSR and its\n       <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">\n        Warsaw Pact\n       </a>\n       allies on the other. The U.S.\n       <a href="/wiki/Containment" title="Containment">\n        developed a policy of containment\n       </a>\n       towards the expansion of communist influence. While the U.S. and Soviet Union engaged in\n       <a href="/wiki/Proxy_war" title="Proxy war">\n        proxy wars\n       </a>\n       and developed powerful nuclear arsenals, the two countries avoided direct military conflict.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The United States often opposed\n       <a href="/wiki/Third_World" title="Third World">\n        Third World\n       </a>\n       movements that it viewed as Soviet-sponsored. American troops fought communist\n       <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army" title="People\'s Liberation Army">\n        Chinese\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">\n        North Korean\n       </a>\n       forces in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">\n        Korean War\n       </a>\n       of 1950\xe2\x80\x9353.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Proxy_183-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Proxy-183">\n         [173]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The Soviet Union\'s 1957 launch of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Sputnik_1" title="Sputnik 1">\n        first artificial satellite\n       </a>\n       and its 1961 launch of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Vostok_1" title="Vostok 1">\n        first manned spaceflight\n       </a>\n       initiated a "\n       <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">\n        Space Race\n       </a>\n       " in which the United States became the first nation to\n       <a href="/wiki/Apollo_11" title="Apollo 11">\n        land a man on the moon\n       </a>\n       in 1969.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Proxy_183-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Proxy-183">\n         [173]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       A proxy war in Southeast Asia eventually evolved into full American participation, as the\n       <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">\n        Vietnam War\n       </a>\n       .\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       At home, the U.S. experienced\n       <a href="/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_economic_expansion" title="Post\xe2\x80\x93World War II economic expansion">\n        sustained economic expansion\n       </a>\n       and a\n       <a href="/wiki/Post%E2%80%93World_War_II_baby_boom" title="Post\xe2\x80\x93World War II baby boom">\n        rapid growth of its population\n       </a>\n       and middle class. Construction of an\n       <a href="/wiki/Interstate_Highway_System" title="Interstate Highway System">\n        Interstate Highway System\n       </a>\n       transformed the nation\'s infrastructure over the following decades. Millions moved from farms and\n       <a href="/wiki/Inner_city" title="Inner city">\n        inner cities\n       </a>\n       to large\n       <a href="/wiki/Suburb" title="Suburb">\n        suburban\n       </a>\n       housing developments.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">\n        <a href="#cite_note-184">\n         [174]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IntHighways_185-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-IntHighways-185">\n         [175]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 1959\n       <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">\n        Hawaii\n       </a>\n       became the 50th and last U.S. state added to the country.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lightner2004_186-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Lightner2004-186">\n         [176]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The growing\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_Rights_Movement" title="Civil Rights Movement">\n        Civil Rights Movement\n       </a>\n       used\n       <a href="/wiki/Nonviolence" title="Nonviolence">\n        nonviolence\n       </a>\n       to confront segregation and discrimination, with\n       <a href="/wiki/Martin_Luther_King_Jr." title="Martin Luther King Jr.">\n        Martin Luther King Jr.\n       </a>\n       becoming a prominent leader and figurehead. A combination of court decisions and legislation, culminating in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Civil_Rights_Act_of_1968" title="Civil Rights Act of 1968">\n        Civil Rights Act of 1968\n       </a>\n       , sought to end racial discrimination.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">\n        <a href="#cite_note-187">\n         [177]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">\n        <a href="#cite_note-188">\n         [178]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">\n        <a href="#cite_note-189">\n         [179]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Meanwhile, a\n       <a href="/wiki/Counterculture_of_the_1960s" title="Counterculture of the 1960s">\n        counterculture movement\n       </a>\n       grew which was fueled by\n       <a href="/wiki/Opposition_to_United_States_involvement_in_the_Vietnam_War" title="Opposition to United States involvement in the Vietnam War">\n        opposition to the Vietnam war\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Black_nationalism" title="Black nationalism">\n        black nationalism\n       </a>\n       , and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Sexual_revolution" title="Sexual revolution">\n        sexual revolution\n       </a>\n       .\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The launch of a "\n       <a href="/wiki/War_on_Poverty" title="War on Poverty">\n        War on Poverty\n       </a>\n       " expanded entitlements and welfare spending, including the creation of\n       <a href="/wiki/Medicare_(United_States)" title="Medicare (United States)">\n        Medicare\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Medicaid" title="Medicaid">\n        Medicaid\n       </a>\n       , two programs that provide health coverage to the elderly and poor, respectively, and the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Means-tested" title="Means-tested">\n        means-tested\n       </a>\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Food_Stamp_Program" title="Food Stamp Program">\n        Food Stamp Program\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Aid_to_Families_with_Dependent_Children" title="Aid to Families with Dependent Children">\n        Aid to Families with Dependent Children\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">\n        <a href="#cite_note-190">\n         [180]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The 1970s and early 1980s saw the onset of\n       <a href="/wiki/Stagflation" title="Stagflation">\n        stagflation\n       </a>\n       . After his election in 1980, President\n       <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">\n        Ronald Reagan\n       </a>\n       responded to economic stagnation with\n       <a href="/wiki/Reaganomics" title="Reaganomics">\n        free-market oriented reforms\n       </a>\n       . Following the collapse of\n       <a href="/wiki/D%C3%A9tente" title="D\xc3\xa9tente">\n        d\xc3\xa9tente\n       </a>\n       , he abandoned "containment" and initiated the more aggressive "\n       <a href="/wiki/Rollback" title="Rollback">\n        rollback\n       </a>\n       " strategy towards the USSR.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">\n        <a href="#cite_note-191">\n         [181]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">\n        <a href="#cite_note-192">\n         [182]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">\n        <a href="#cite_note-193">\n         [183]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">\n        <a href="#cite_note-194">\n         [184]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">\n        <a href="#cite_note-195">\n         [185]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       After a surge in female labor participation over the previous decade, by 1985 the majority of women aged 16 and over were employed.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">\n        <a href="#cite_note-196">\n         [186]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The late 1980s brought a "\n       <a href="/wiki/Cold_War_(1985%E2%80%9391)" title="Cold War (1985\xe2\x80\x9391)">\n        thaw\n       </a>\n       " in relations with the USSR, and\n       <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">\n        its collapse\n       </a>\n       in 1991 finally ended the Cold War.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">\n        <a href="#cite_note-197">\n         [187]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198">\n        <a href="#cite_note-198">\n         [188]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">\n        <a href="#cite_note-199">\n         [189]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">\n        <a href="#cite_note-200">\n         [190]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       This brought about\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unipolarity" title="Unipolarity">\n        unipolarity\n       </a>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">\n        <a href="#cite_note-201">\n         [191]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       with the U.S. unchallenged as the world\'s dominant superpower. The concept of\n       <a href="/wiki/Pax_Americana" title="Pax Americana">\n        Pax Americana\n       </a>\n       , which had appeared in the post-World War II period, gained wide popularity as a term for the post-Cold War\n       <a href="/wiki/New_world_order_(politics)" title="New world order (politics)">\n        new world order.\n       </a>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Contemporary_history">\n        Contemporary history\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main articles:\n       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(1991%E2%80%932008)" title="History of the United States (1991\xe2\x80\x932008)">\n        History of the United States (1991\xe2\x80\x932008)\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_(2008%E2%80%93present)" title="History of the United States (2008\xe2\x80\x93present)">\n        History of the United States (2008\xe2\x80\x93present)\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Further information:\n       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">\n        Gulf War\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">\n        September 11 attacks\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/War_on_Terror" title="War on Terror">\n        War on Terror\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_financial_crisis" title="2008 financial crisis">\n        2008 financial crisis\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Affordable_Care_Act" title="Affordable Care Act">\n        Affordable Care Act\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:368px;max-width:368px">\n        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:242px;max-width:242px">\n         <div class="thumbimage">\n          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg">\n           <img alt="" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg/240px-WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg/360px-WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg/480px-WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg 2x" width="240"/>\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">\n          The\n          <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973\xe2\x80\x932001)">\n           World Trade Center\n          </a>\n          in\n          <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">\n           Lower Manhattan\n          </a>\n          during the\n          <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">\n           September 11 attacks\n          </a>\n          in 2001\n         </div>\n        </div>\n        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:122px;max-width:122px">\n         <div class="thumbimage">\n          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg">\n           <img alt="" data-file-height="1187" data-file-width="788" height="181" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg/120px-OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg/180px-OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg/240px-OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg 2x" width="120"/>\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">\n          <a href="/wiki/One_World_Trade_Center" title="One World Trade Center">\n           One World Trade Center\n          </a>\n          , newly-built in its place\n         </div>\n        </div>\n        <div style="clear:left">\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       After the Cold War, the conflict in the Middle East triggered a crisis in 1990, when\n       <a href="/wiki/Ba%27athist_Iraq" title="Ba\'athist Iraq">\n        Iraq\n       </a>\n       under\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sadaam_Hussein" title="Sadaam Hussein">\n        Sadaam Hussein\n       </a>\n       <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Kuwait" title="Invasion of Kuwait">\n        invaded and attempted to annex Kuwait\n       </a>\n       , an ally of the United States. Fearing that the instability would spread to other regions, President\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/George_H.W._Bush" title="George H.W. Bush">\n        George H.W. Bush\n       </a>\n       launched\n       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">\n        Operation Desert Shield\n       </a>\n       , a defensive force buildup in Saudi Arabia, and\n       <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">\n        Operation Desert Storm\n       </a>\n       , in a staging titled the Gulf War; waged by\n       <a href="/wiki/Coalition_of_the_Gulf_War" title="Coalition of the Gulf War">\n        coalition forces\n       </a>\n       from 34 nations, led by the United States against Iraq ending in the successful expulsion of Iraqi forces from Kuwait, restoring the former monarchy.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">\n        <a href="#cite_note-202">\n         [192]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Originating in\n       <a href="/wiki/ARPANET" title="ARPANET">\n        U.S. defense networks\n       </a>\n       , the\n       <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">\n        Internet\n       </a>\n       spread to international academic networks, and then to the public in the 1990s, greatly affecting the global economy, society, and culture.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">\n        <a href="#cite_note-203">\n         [193]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Due to the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dot-com_boom" title="Dot-com boom">\n        dot-com boom\n       </a>\n       , stable monetary policy under\n       <a href="/wiki/Alan_Greenspan" title="Alan Greenspan">\n        Alan Greenspan\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Personal_Responsibility_and_Work_Opportunity_Act" title="Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Act">\n        reduced social welfare spending\n       </a>\n       , the 1990s saw the\n       <a href="/wiki/1990s_United_States_boom" title="1990s United States boom">\n        longest economic expansion\n       </a>\n       in modern U.S. history, ending in 2001.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">\n        <a href="#cite_note-204">\n         [194]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Beginning in 1994, the U.S. entered into the\n       <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">\n        North American Free Trade Agreement\n       </a>\n       (NAFTA), linking 450 million people producing $17 trillion worth of goods and services. The goal of the agreement was to eliminate trade and investment barriers among the U.S., Canada, and Mexico by January 1, 2008. Trade among the three partners has soared since NAFTA went into force.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">\n        <a href="#cite_note-205">\n         [195]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       On\n       <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">\n        September 11, 2001\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">\n        Al-Qaeda\n       </a>\n       terrorists struck the\n       <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973\xe2\x80\x932001)">\n        World Trade Center\n       </a>\n       in New York City and\n       <a href="/wiki/The_Pentagon" title="The Pentagon">\n        the Pentagon\n       </a>\n       near Washington, D.C., killing nearly 3,000 people.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">\n        <a href="#cite_note-206">\n         [196]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In response, the United States launched the\n       <a href="/wiki/War_on_Terror" title="War on Terror">\n        War on Terror\n       </a>\n       , which included\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932014)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001\xe2\x80\x932014)">\n        war in Afghanistan\n       </a>\n       and the 2003\xe2\x80\x9311\n       <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">\n        Iraq War\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">\n        <a href="#cite_note-207">\n         [197]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">\n        <a href="#cite_note-208">\n         [198]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2007, the Bush administration ordered a major\n       <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War_troop_surge_of_2007" title="Iraq War troop surge of 2007">\n        troop surge in the Iraq War\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fact_209-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-fact-209">\n         [199]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       which successfully reduced violence and led to greater stability in the region.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Feaver_210-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Feaver-210">\n         [200]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">\n        <a href="#cite_note-211">\n         [201]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Government policy designed to promote affordable housing,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">\n        <a href="#cite_note-212">\n         [202]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       widespread failures in corporate and regulatory governance,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">\n        <a href="#cite_note-213">\n         [203]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and historically low interest rates set by the Federal Reserve\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">\n        <a href="#cite_note-214">\n         [204]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       led to the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_housing_bubble" title="United States housing bubble">\n        mid-2000s housing bubble\n       </a>\n       , which culminated with the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_financial_crisis" title="2008 financial crisis">\n        2008 financial crisis\n       </a>\n       , the largest economic contraction in the nation\'s history since the Great Depression.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">\n        <a href="#cite_note-215">\n         [205]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">\n        Barack Obama\n       </a>\n       , the first\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">\n        African American\n       </a>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">\n        <a href="#cite_note-216">\n         [206]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multiracial_American" title="Multiracial American">\n        multiracial\n       </a>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">\n        <a href="#cite_note-217">\n         [207]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       president,\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2008" title="United States presidential election, 2008">\n        was elected in 2008\n       </a>\n       amid the crisis,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">\n        <a href="#cite_note-218">\n         [208]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and subsequently passed\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_Reinvestment_and_Recovery_Act" title="American Reinvestment and Recovery Act">\n        stimulus measures\n       </a>\n       and the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dodd-Frank_Wall_Street_Reform_and_Consumer_Protection_Act" title="Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act">\n        Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act\n       </a>\n       in an attempt to mitigate its negative effects and ensure there would not be a repeat of the crisis. The stimulus facilitated infrastructure improvements\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">\n        <a href="#cite_note-219">\n         [209]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and a relative decline in unemployment.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">\n        <a href="#cite_note-220">\n         [210]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Dodd-Frank improved financial stability and consumer protection,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">\n        <a href="#cite_note-221">\n         [211]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       although there is evidence it may have had a negative impact on small banks.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">\n        <a href="#cite_note-222">\n         [212]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In 2010, the Obama administration passed the\n       <a href="/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" title="Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">\n        Affordable Care Act\n       </a>\n       , which made the most sweeping reforms to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_the_United_States" title="Health care in the United States">\n        nation\'s healthcare system\n       </a>\n       in nearly five decades, including\n       <a href="/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act#Mandates" title="Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">\n        mandates\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Premium_tax_credit" title="Premium tax credit">\n        subsidies\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Health_insurance_marketplace" title="Health insurance marketplace">\n        insurance exchanges\n       </a>\n       . The law caused a significant reduction in the number and percentage of people without health insurance, with 24 million covered during 2016,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBO_Subsidy2016_223-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CBO_Subsidy2016-223">\n         [213]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       but remains controversial due to its impact on healthcare costs, insurance premiums, and economic performance.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">\n        <a href="#cite_note-224">\n         [214]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Although the recession reached its trough in June 2009, voters remained frustrated with the slow pace of the economic recovery. The Republicans, who stood in opposition to Obama\'s policies, won control of the House of Representatives with\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections,_2010" title="United States House of Representatives elections, 2010">\n        a landslide in 2010\n       </a>\n       and control of the Senate in\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Senate_elections,_2014" title="United States Senate elections, 2014">\n        2014\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">\n        <a
