href="/wiki/Spain%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Spain\xe2\x80\x93United States relations">\n        Spain\n       </a>\n       . It works closely with fellow\n       <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">\n        NATO\n       </a>\n       members on military and security issues and with its neighbors through the\n       <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">\n        Organization of American States\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_free_trade_agreements" title="United States free trade agreements">\n        free trade agreements\n       </a>\n       such as the trilateral\n       <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">\n        North American Free Trade Agreement\n       </a>\n       with Canada and\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexico%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Mexico\xe2\x80\x93United States relations">\n        Mexico\n       </a>\n       . In 2008, the United States spent a net $25.4 billion on\n       <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">\n        official development assistance\n       </a>\n       , the most in the world. As a share of America\'s large\n       <a href="/wiki/Gross_national_income" title="Gross national income">\n        gross national income\n       </a>\n       (GNI), however, the U.S. contribution of 0.18% ranked last among 22 donor states. By contrast, private overseas giving by Americans is relatively generous.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398">\n        <a href="#cite_note-398">\n         [385]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The U.S. exercises full international defense authority and responsibility for three sovereign nations through\n       <a href="/wiki/Compact_of_Free_Association" title="Compact of Free Association">\n        Compact of Free Association\n       </a>\n       with\n       <a href="/wiki/Federated_States_of_Micronesia" title="Federated States of Micronesia">\n        Micronesia\n       </a>\n       , the\n       <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Islands" title="Marshall Islands">\n        Marshall Islands\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">\n        Palau\n       </a>\n       . These are Pacific island nations, once part of the U.S.-administered\n       <a href="/wiki/Trust_Territory_of_the_Pacific_Islands" title="Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands">\n        Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands\n       </a>\n       after World War II, which gained independence in subsequent years.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399">\n        <a href="#cite_note-399">\n         [386]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       On October 25, 2017, Vice President Mike Pence announced at a\n       <i>\n        In Defense of Christians\n       </i>\n       annual dinner meeting in Washington that the United States would stop funding United Nations relief efforts, cases tackling the persecution of Christians in the Middle East, but insisted that the U.S. would instead help and aid Christians directly through the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Agency_for_International_Development" title="U.S. Agency for International Development">\n        U.S. Agency for International Development\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400">\n        <a href="#cite_note-400">\n         [387]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Pence said that he will be visiting the Middle East in December and will meet with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas to discuss peace agreements.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401">\n        <a href="#cite_note-401">\n         [388]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402">\n        <a href="#cite_note-402">\n         [389]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Government_finance">\n        Government finance\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       See also:\n       <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_the_United_States" title="Taxation in the United States">\n        Taxation in the United States\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_federal_budget" title="United States federal budget">\n        United States federal budget\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:427px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="310" data-file-width="850" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png/425px-Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png/638px-Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/36/Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png 2x" width="425"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Federal_Debt_Held_by_the_Public_1790-2013.png" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         US federal debt held by the public as a percentage of GDP, from 1790 to 2013.\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403">\n          <a href="#cite_note-403">\n           [390]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_the_United_States" title="Taxation in the United States">\n        Taxes in the United States\n       </a>\n       are levied at the federal, state, and local government levels. These include taxes on income, payroll, property, sales, imports, estates and gifts, as well as various fees. In 2010 taxes collected by federal, state and municipal governments amounted to 24.8% of\n       <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">\n        GDP\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404">\n        <a href="#cite_note-404">\n         [391]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       During FY2012, the federal government collected approximately $2.45 trillion in tax revenue, up $147 billion or 6% versus FY2011 revenues of $2.30 trillion. Primary receipt categories included individual income taxes ($1,132B or 47%), Social Security/Social Insurance taxes ($845B or 35%), and corporate taxes ($242B or 10%).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBO_Historical_Tables_2012FY_405-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CBO_Historical_Tables_2012FY-405">\n         [392]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Based on CBO estimates,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBO_2010_406-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CBO_2010-406">\n         [393]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       under 2013 tax law the top 1% will be paying the highest average tax rates since 1979, while other income groups will remain at historic lows.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lowrey_407-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Lowrey-407">\n         [394]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       U.S. taxation is generally\n       <a href="/wiki/Progressive_tax" title="Progressive tax">\n        progressive\n       </a>\n       , especially the federal income taxes, and is among the most progressive in the developed world.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408">\n        <a href="#cite_note-408">\n         [395]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409">\n        <a href="#cite_note-409">\n         [396]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410">\n        <a href="#cite_note-410">\n         [397]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dylan47_411-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Dylan47-411">\n         [398]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412">\n        <a href="#cite_note-412">\n         [399]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The highest 10% of income earners pay a majority of federal taxes,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413">\n        <a href="#cite_note-413">\n         [400]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and about half of all taxes.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414">\n        <a href="#cite_note-414">\n         [401]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Payroll taxes for Social Security are a flat\n       <a href="/wiki/Regressive_tax" title="Regressive tax">\n        regressive tax\n       </a>\n       , with no tax charged on income above $118,500 (for 2015 and 2016) and no tax at all paid on\n       <a href="/wiki/Unearned_income" title="Unearned income">\n        unearned income\n       </a>\n       from things such as stocks and capital gains.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415">\n        <a href="#cite_note-415">\n         [402]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416">\n        <a href="#cite_note-416">\n         [403]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The historic reasoning for the regressive nature of the payroll tax is that entitlement programs have not been viewed as welfare transfers.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417">\n        <a href="#cite_note-417">\n         [404]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418">\n        <a href="#cite_note-418">\n         [405]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       However, according to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Congressional_Budget_Office" title="Congressional Budget Office">\n        Congressional Budget Office\n       </a>\n       the net effect of Social Security is that the benefit to tax ratio ranges from roughly 70% for the top earnings quintile to about 170% for the lowest earning quintile, making the system progressive.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419">\n        <a href="#cite_note-419">\n         [406]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The top 10% paid 51.8% of total federal taxes in 2009, and the top 1%, with 13.4% of pre-tax national income, paid 22.3% of federal taxes.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBO.2C_Distribution_420-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CBO.2C_Distribution-420">\n         [407]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2013 the Tax Policy Center projected total federal effective tax rates of 35.5% for the top 1%, 27.2% for the top quintile, 13.8% for the middle quintile, and \xe2\x88\x922.7% for the bottom quintile.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421">\n        <a href="#cite_note-421">\n         [408]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422">\n        <a href="#cite_note-422">\n         [409]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Tax_incidence" title="Tax incidence">\n        incidence\n       </a>\n       of\n       <a href="/wiki/Corporate_tax_in_the_United_States" title="Corporate tax in the United States">\n        corporate income tax\n       </a>\n       has been a matter of considerable ongoing controversy for decades.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dylan47_411-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Dylan47-411">\n         [398]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423">\n        <a href="#cite_note-423">\n         [410]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       State and local taxes vary widely, but are generally less progressive than federal taxes as they rely heavily on broadly borne\n       <a href="/wiki/Regressive_tax" title="Regressive tax">\n        regressive\n       </a>\n       sales and property taxes that yield less volatile revenue streams, though their consideration does not eliminate the progressive nature of overall taxation.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dylan47_411-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Dylan47-411">\n         [398]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TaxF_424-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-TaxF-424">\n         [411]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       During FY 2012, the federal government spent $3.54 trillion on a budget or cash basis, down $60 billion or 1.7% vs. FY 2011 spending of $3.60 trillion. Major categories of FY 2012 spending included: Medicare &amp; Medicaid ($802B or 23% of spending), Social Security ($768B or 22%), Defense Department ($670B or 19%), non-defense discretionary ($615B or 17%), other mandatory ($461B or 13%) and interest ($223B or 6%).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CBO_Historical_Tables_2012FY_405-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CBO_Historical_Tables_2012FY-405">\n         [392]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The total\n       <a href="/wiki/National_debt_of_the_United_States" title="National debt of the United States">\n        national debt of the United States\n       </a>\n       in the United States was $18.527 trillion (106% of the GDP) in 2014.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425">\n        <a href="#cite_note-425">\n         [412]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430">\n        <a href="#cite_note-430">\n         [fn 14]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Military">\n        Military\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">\n        United States Armed Forces\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_060618-N-8492C-212_An_Air_Force_B-2_bomber_along_with_other_aircrafts_from_the_Air_Force,_Navy_and_Marine_Corps_fly_over_the_Kitty_Hawk,_Ronald_Reagan_and_Abraham_Lincoln_Carrier_Strike_groups.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3008" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/US_Navy_060618-N-8492C-212_An_Air_Force_B-2_bomber_along_with_other_aircrafts_from_the_Air_Force%2C_Navy_and_Marine_Corps_fly_over_the_Kitty_Hawk%2C_Ronald_Reagan_and_Abraham_Lincoln_Carrier_Strike_groups.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/US_Navy_060618-N-8492C-212_An_Air_Force_B-2_bomber_along_with_other_aircrafts_from_the_Air_Force%2C_Navy_and_Marine_Corps_fly_over_the_Kitty_Hawk%2C_Ronald_Reagan_and_Abraham_Lincoln_Carrier_Strike_groups.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/US_Navy_060618-N-8492C-212_An_Air_Force_B-2_bomber_along_with_other_aircrafts_from_the_Air_Force%2C_Navy_and_Marine_Corps_fly_over_the_Kitty_Hawk%2C_Ronald_Reagan_and_Abraham_Lincoln_Carrier_Strike_groups.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:US_Navy_060618-N-8492C-212_An_Air_Force_B-2_bomber_along_with_other_aircrafts_from_the_Air_Force,_Navy_and_Marine_Corps_fly_over_the_Kitty_Hawk,_Ronald_Reagan_and_Abraham_Lincoln_Carrier_Strike_groups.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The\n         <a href="/wiki/Carrier_strike_group" title="Carrier strike group">\n          carrier strike groups\n         </a>\n         of the\n         <i>\n          <a href="/wiki/USS_Kitty_Hawk_(CV-63)" title="USS Kitty Hawk (CV-63)">\n           Kitty Hawk\n          </a>\n         </i>\n         ,\n         <i>\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USS_Ronald_Reagan_(CVN-76)" title="USS Ronald Reagan (CVN-76)">\n           Ronald Reagan\n          </a>\n         </i>\n         , and\n         <i>\n          <a href="/wiki/USS_Abraham_Lincoln_(CVN-72)" title="USS Abraham Lincoln (CVN-72)">\n           Abraham Lincoln\n          </a>\n         </i>\n         with aircraft from the\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps" title="United States Marine Corps">\n          Marine Corps\n         </a>\n         ,\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy" title="United States Navy">\n          Navy\n         </a>\n         , and\n         <a href="/wiki/United_States_Air_Force" title="United States Air Force">\n          Air Force\n         </a>\n         .\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The President holds the title of\n       <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">\n        commander-in-chief\n       </a>\n       of the nation\'s armed forces and appoints its leaders, the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_Defense" title="United States Secretary of Defense">\n        Secretary of Defense\n       </a>\n       and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Joint_Chiefs_of_Staff" title="Joint Chiefs of Staff">\n        Joint Chiefs of Staff\n       </a>\n       . The\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense" title="United States Department of Defense">\n        United States Department of Defense\n       </a>\n       administers the armed forces, including the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army" title="United States Army">\n        Army\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Marine_Corps" title="United States Marine Corps">\n        Marine Corps\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Navy" title="United States Navy">\n        Navy\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Air_Force" title="United States Air Force">\n        Air Force\n       </a>\n       . The\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Coast_Guard" title="United States Coast Guard">\n        Coast Guard\n       </a>\n       is run by the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Homeland_Security" title="United States Department of Homeland Security">\n        Department of Homeland Security\n       </a>\n       in peacetime and by the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Navy" title="United States Department of the Navy">\n        Department of the Navy\n       </a>\n       during times of war. In 2008, the armed forces had 1.4 million personnel on active duty. The\n       <a href="/wiki/Reserve_components_of_the_United_States_Armed_Forces" title="Reserve components of the United States Armed Forces">\n        Reserves\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/National_Guard_of_the_United_States" title="National Guard of the United States">\n        National Guard\n       </a>\n       brought the total number of troops to 2.3 million. The Department of Defense also employed about 700,000 civilians, not including contractors.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431">\n        <a href="#cite_note-431">\n         [417]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Military service is voluntary, though\n       <a href="/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States" title="Conscription in the United States">\n        conscription\n       </a>\n       may occur in wartime through the\n       <a href="/wiki/Selective_Service_System" title="Selective Service System">\n        Selective Service System\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432">\n        <a href="#cite_note-432">\n         [418]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       American forces can be rapidly deployed by the Air Force\'s large fleet of transport aircraft, the Navy\'s 11 active\n       <a href="/wiki/Aircraft_carrier" title="Aircraft carrier">\n        aircraft carriers\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Marine_expeditionary_unit" title="Marine expeditionary unit">\n        Marine expeditionary units\n       </a>\n       at sea with the Navy\'s\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Fleet_Forces_Command" title="United States Fleet Forces Command">\n        Atlantic and\n       </a>\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Pacific_Fleet" title="United States Pacific Fleet">\n        Pacific fleets\n       </a>\n       . The military operates 865 bases and facilities abroad,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433">\n        <a href="#cite_note-433">\n         [419]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and maintains\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_military_deployments" title="United States military deployments">\n        deployments greater than 100 active duty personnel\n       </a>\n       in 25 foreign countries.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434">\n        <a href="#cite_note-434">\n         [420]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Military_budget_of_the_United_States" title="Military budget of the United States">\n        military budget of the United States\n       </a>\n       in 2011 was more than $700 billion, 41% of global military spending and equal to the next 14 largest national military expenditures combined. At 4.7% of GDP, the rate was the second-highest among the top 15 military spenders, after\n       <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">\n        Saudi Arabia\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435">\n        <a href="#cite_note-435">\n         [421]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       U.S. defense spending as a percentage of GDP ranked 23rd globally in 2012 according to the CIA.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436">\n        <a href="#cite_note-436">\n         [422]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Defense\'s share of U.S. spending has generally declined in recent decades, from Cold War peaks of 14.2% of GDP in 1953 and 69.5% of federal outlays in 1954 to 4.7% of GDP and 18.8% of federal outlays in 2011.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437">\n        <a href="#cite_note-437">\n         [423]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:US_Global_Military_Presence.svg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="477" data-file-width="940" height="112" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/US_Global_Military_Presence.svg/220px-US_Global_Military_Presence.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/US_Global_Military_Presence.svg/330px-US_Global_Military_Presence.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/US_Global_Military_Presence.svg/440px-US_Global_Military_Presence.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:US_Global_Military_Presence.svg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         US global military presence.\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The proposed base\n       <a href="/wiki/Military_budget_of_the_United_States" title="Military budget of the United States">\n        Department of Defense budget\n       </a>\n       for 2012, $553 billion, was a 4.2% increase over 2011; an additional $118 billion was proposed for the military campaigns in Iraq and Afghanistan.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438">\n        <a href="#cite_note-438">\n         [424]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The last American troops serving in Iraq departed in December 2011;\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439">\n        <a href="#cite_note-439">\n         [425]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       4,484 service members were killed during the\n       <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">\n        Iraq War\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440">\n        <a href="#cite_note-440">\n         [426]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Approximately 90,000 U.S. troops were serving in Afghanistan in April 2012;\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Frontline_Turning_Point_441-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Frontline_Turning_Point-441">\n         [427]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       by November 8, 2013 2,285 had been killed during the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932014)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001\xe2\x80\x932014)">\n        War in Afghanistan\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442">\n        <a href="#cite_note-442">\n         [428]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement_and_crime">\n        Law enforcement and crime\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main articles:\n       <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_the_United_States" title="Law enforcement in the United States">\n        Law enforcement in the United States\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_the_United_States" title="Crime in the United States">\n        Crime in the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       See also:\n       <a href="/wiki/Law_of_the_United_States" title="Law of the United States">\n        Law of the United States\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Second Amendment to the United States Constitution">\n        Second Amendment to the United States Constitution\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_the_United_States#Justice_system" title="Human rights in the United States">\n        Human rights in the United States \xc2\xa7\xc2\xa0Justice system\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Incarceration_in_the_United_States" title="Incarceration in the United States">\n        Incarceration in the United States\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_the_United_States" title="Capital punishment in the United States">\n        Capital punishment in the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2912" data-file-width="4368" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg/220px-Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg/330px-Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg/440px-Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Santa_Fe_police_3.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Law enforcement in the U.S. is maintained primarily by local police departments.\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443">\n          <a href="#cite_note-443">\n           [429]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Law enforcement in the United States is primarily the responsibility of local police and\n       <a href="/wiki/Sheriff" title="Sheriff">\n        sheriff\n       </a>\n       \'s departments, with\n       <a href="/wiki/State_police" title="State police">\n        state police\n       </a>\n       providing broader services. The\n       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department" title="New York City Police Department">\n        New York City Police Department\n       </a>\n       (NYPD) is the largest in the country. Federal agencies such as the\n       <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation" title="Federal Bureau of Investigation">\n        Federal Bureau of Investigation\n       </a>\n       (FBI) and the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Marshals_Service" title="United States Marshals Service">\n        U.S. Marshals Service\n       </a>\n       have specialized duties, including protecting\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Civil_rights" title="Civil rights">\n        civil rights\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Security_of_the_United_States" title="National Security of the United States">\n        national security\n       </a>\n       and enforcing\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._federal_courts" title="U.S. federal courts">\n        U.S. federal courts\n       </a>\n       \' rulings and federal laws.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444">\n        <a href="#cite_note-444">\n         [430]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       At the federal level and in almost every state, a legal system operates on a\n       <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">\n        common law\n       </a>\n       . State courts conduct most criminal trials;\n       <a href="/wiki/Federal_judiciary_of_the_United_States" title="Federal judiciary of the United States">\n        federal courts\n       </a>\n       handle certain designated crimes as well as certain appeals from the state criminal courts.\n       <a href="/wiki/Plea_bargaining_in_the_United_States" title="Plea bargaining in the United States">\n        Plea bargaining in the United States\n       </a>\n       is very common; the vast majority of criminal cases in the country are settled by\n       <a href="/wiki/Plea_bargain" title="Plea bargain">\n        plea bargain\n       </a>\n       rather than\n       <a href="/wiki/Jury_trial" title="Jury trial">\n        jury trial\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445">\n        <a href="#cite_note-445">\n         [431]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In 2015, there were 15,696 murders which was 1,532 more than in 2014, a 10.8 per cent increase, the largest since 1971.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446">\n        <a href="#cite_note-446">\n         [432]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The murder rate in 2015 was 4.9 per 100,000 people.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447">\n        <a href="#cite_note-447">\n         [433]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2016 the murder rate increased by 8.6%, with 17,250 murders that year.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448">\n        <a href="#cite_note-448">\n         [434]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The national\n       <a href="/wiki/Clearance_rate" title="Clearance rate">\n        clearance rate\n       </a>\n       for homicides in 2015 was 64.1%, compared to 90% in 1965.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449">\n        <a href="#cite_note-449">\n         [435]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2012 there were 4.7 murders per 100,000 persons in the United States, a 54% decline from the modern peak of 10.2 in 1980.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450">\n        <a href="#cite_note-450">\n         [436]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2001\xe2\x80\x932, the United States had above-average levels of violent crime and particularly high levels of\n       <a href="/wiki/Gun_violence_in_the_United_States" title="Gun violence in the United States">\n        gun violence\n       </a>\n       compared to other developed nations.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451">\n        <a href="#cite_note-451">\n         [437]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       A cross-sectional analysis of the\n       <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">\n        World Health Organization\n       </a>\n       Mortality Database from 2010 showed that United States "homicide rates were 7.0 times higher than in other high-income countries, driven by a gun homicide rate that was 25.2 times higher."\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452">\n        <a href="#cite_note-452">\n         [438]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/Second_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution" title="Second Amendment to the United States Constitution">\n        Gun ownership rights\n       </a>\n       continue to be the subject of\n       <a href="/wiki/Gun_politics_in_the_United_States" title="Gun politics in the United States">\n        contentious political debate\n       </a>\n       .\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       From 1980 through 2008 males represented 77% of homicide victims and 90% of offenders. Blacks committed 52.5% of all homicides during that span, at a rate almost eight times that of whites ("whites" includes most Hispanics), and were victimized at a rate six times that of whites. Most homicides were intraracial, with 93% of black victims killed by blacks and 84% of white victims killed by whites.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453">\n        <a href="#cite_note-453">\n         [439]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2012, Louisiana had the highest rate of murder and non-negligent manslaughter in the U.S., and New Hampshire the lowest.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454">\n        <a href="#cite_note-454">\n         [440]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The FBI\'s\n       <a href="/wiki/Uniform_Crime_Reports" title="Uniform Crime Reports">\n        Uniform Crime Reports\n       </a>\n       estimates that there were 3,246 violent and property crimes per 100,000 residents in 2012, for a total of over 9 million total crimes.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455">\n        <a href="#cite_note-455">\n         [441]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment" title="Capital punishment">\n        Capital punishment\n       </a>\n       is sanctioned in the United States for certain federal and military crimes, and used in 31 states.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456">\n        <a href="#cite_note-456">\n         [442]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457">\n        <a href="#cite_note-457">\n         [443]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       No executions took place from 1967 to 1977, owing in part to a\n       <a href="/wiki/Furman_v._Georgia" title="Furman v. Georgia">\n        U.S. Supreme Court ruling\n       </a>\n       striking down arbitrary imposition of the death penalty. In 1976, that Court ruled that, under appropriate circumstances, capital punishment may constitutionally be imposed. Since the decision there have been more than 1,300 executions, a majority of these taking place in three states: Texas, Virginia, and\n       <a href="/wiki/Oklahoma" title="Oklahoma">\n        Oklahoma\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458">\n        <a href="#cite_note-458">\n         [444]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Meanwhile,\n       <a href="/wiki/Capital_punishment_in_the_United_States#States_without_capital_punishment" title="Capital punishment in the United States">\n        several states\n       </a>\n       have either abolished or struck down death penalty laws. In 2015, the country had the fifth-highest number of executions in the world, following China,\n       <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">\n        Iran\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">\n        Pakistan\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">\n        Saudi Arabia\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459">\n        <a href="#cite_note-459">\n         [445]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The United States has the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_incarceration_rate" title="United States incarceration rate">\n        highest documented incarceration rate\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Incarceration_in_the_United_States" title="Incarceration in the United States">\n        total prison population\n       </a>\n       in the world.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460">\n        <a href="#cite_note-460">\n         [446]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       At the start of 2008, more than 2.3 million people were incarcerated, more than one in every 100 adults.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461">\n        <a href="#cite_note-461">\n         [447]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In December 2012, the combined U.S. adult correctional systems supervised about 6,937,600 offenders. About 1 in every 35 adult residents in the United States was under some form of correctional supervision in December 2012, the lowest rate observed since 1997.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462">\n        <a href="#cite_note-462">\n         [448]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The prison population has quadrupled since 1980,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463">\n        <a href="#cite_note-463">\n         [449]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and state and local spending on prisons and jails has grown three times as much as that spent on public education during the same period.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464">\n        <a href="#cite_note-464">\n         [450]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       However, the imprisonment rate for all prisoners sentenced to more than a year in state or federal facilities is 478 per 100,000 in 2013\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465">\n        <a href="#cite_note-465">\n         [451]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and the rate for pre-trial/remand prisoners is 153 per 100,000 residents in 2012.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466">\n        <a href="#cite_note-466">\n         [452]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The country\'s high rate of incarceration is largely due to changes in\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Federal_Sentencing_Guidelines" title="United States Federal Sentencing Guidelines">\n        sentencing guidelines\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Federal_drug_policy_of_the_United_States" title="Federal drug policy of the United States">\n        drug policies\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ClearCole2008b_467-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-ClearCole2008b-467">\n         [453]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       According to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Prisons" title="Federal Bureau of Prisons">\n        Federal Bureau of Prisons\n       </a>\n       , the majority of inmates held in federal prisons are convicted of drug offenses.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468">\n        <a href="#cite_note-468">\n         [454]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Incarceration_in_the_United_States#Privatization" title="Incarceration in the United States">\n        privatization of prisons\n       </a>\n       and prison services which began in the 1980s has been a subject of debate.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469">\n        <a href="#cite_note-469">\n         [455]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470">\n        <a href="#cite_note-470">\n         [456]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2008, Louisiana\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_incarceration_rate#Incarceration_rate_by_state" title="List of U.S. states by incarceration rate">\n        had the highest incarceration rate\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471">\n        <a href="#cite_note-471">\n         [457]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and Maine the lowest.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472">\n        <a href="#cite_note-472">\n         [458]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">\n        Economy\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_States" title="Economy of the United States">\n        Economy of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       See also:\n       <a href="/wiki/Economic_history_of_the_United_States" title="Economic history of the United States">\n        Economic history of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <table class="infobox" style="font-size: 90%; border: 1px solid #999; float: right; margin-left: 1em; width:325px">\n       <tr style="background:#f5f5f5">\n        <th colspan="3">\n         Economic indicators\n        </th>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         Nominal\n         <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">\n          GDP\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $18.45 trillion\n         <small>\n          (Q2 2016)\n         </small>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BEA_473-0">\n          <a href="#cite_note-BEA-473">\n           [459]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         Real GDP growth\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         3.0%\n         <small>\n          (Q3 2017)\n         </small>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BEA_473-1">\n          <a href="#cite_note-BEA-473">\n           [459]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         2.6%\n         <small>\n          (2015)\n         </small>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474">\n          <a href="#cite_note-474">\n           [460]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Consumer_price_index" title="Consumer price index">\n          CPI\n         </a>\n         inflation\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         2.2%\n         <small>\n          (September 2017)\n         </small>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475">\n          <a href="#cite_note-475">\n           [461]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Employment-to-population_ratio" title="Employment-to-population ratio">\n          Employment-to-population ratio\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         60.2%\n         <small>\n          (October 2017)\n         </small>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476">\n          <a href="#cite_note-476">\n           [462]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Unemployment_in_the_United_States" title="Unemployment in the United States">\n          Unemployment\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         4.1%\n         <small>\n          (October 2017)\n         </small>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477">\n          <a href="#cite_note-477">\n           [463]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labor_force#Labor_force_in_the_United_States" title="Labor force">\n          Labor force\n         </a>\n         participation rate\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         62.7%\n         <small>\n          (November 2017)\n         </small>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478">\n          <a href="#cite_note-478">\n           [464]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/National_debt_of_the_United_States" title="National debt of the United States">\n          Total public debt\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $19.808 trillion\n         <small>\n          (October 25, 2016)\n         </small>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479">\n          <a href="#cite_note-479">\n           [465]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         <a href="/wiki/Wealth_in_the_United_States" title="Wealth in the United States">\n          Household net worth\n         </a>\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $96.196 trillion\n         <small>\n          (Q2 2017)\n         </small>\n        </td>\n        <td style="text-align:right;">\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480">\n          <a href="#cite_note-480">\n           [466]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n      </table>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:317px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:United_States_Export_Treemap_(2011).png">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="582" data-file-width="753" height="243" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/United_States_Export_Treemap_%282011%29.png/315px-United_States_Export_Treemap_%282011%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/United_States_Export_Treemap_%282011%29.png/473px-United_States_Export_Treemap_%282011%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/United_States_Export_Treemap_%282011%29.png/630px-United_States_Export_Treemap_%282011%29.png 2x" width="315"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:United_States_Export_Treemap_(2011).png" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         United States export treemap (2011): The U.S. is the world\'s second-largest exporter.\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The United States has a\n       <a href="/wiki/Capitalism" title="Capitalism">\n        capitalist\n       </a>\n       <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">\n        mixed economy\n       </a>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481">\n        <a href="#cite_note-481">\n         [467]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       which is fueled by abundant\n       <a href="/wiki/Natural_resource" title="Natural resource">\n        natural resources\n       </a>\n       and high productivity.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-482">\n        <a href="#cite_note-482">\n         [468]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       According to the\n       <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">\n        International Monetary Fund\n       </a>\n       , the U.S. GDP of $16.8 trillion constitutes 24% of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Gross_world_product" title="Gross world product">\n        gross world product\n       </a>\n       at market exchange rates and over 19% of the gross world product at\n       <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">\n        purchasing power parity\n       </a>\n       (PPP).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMF_GDP_483-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-IMF_GDP-483">\n         [469]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The nominal GDP of the U.S. is estimated to be $17.528 trillion as of 2014\n       <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">\n        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit">\n         [update]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484">\n        <a href="#cite_note-484">\n         [470]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       From 1983 to 2008, U.S. real compounded annual GDP growth was 3.3%, compared to a 2.3% weighted average for the rest of the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G7" title="G7">\n        G7\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hagopian_485-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Hagopian-485">\n         [471]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The country ranks ninth in the world in\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal) per capita">\n        nominal GDP per capita\n       </a>\n       (first in the Americas)\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMFNorthAmericaGDP_40-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-IMFNorthAmericaGDP-40">\n         [33]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMFSouthAmericaGDP_39-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-IMFSouthAmericaGDP-39">\n         [32]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and sixth in\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">\n        GDP per capita at PPP\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMF_GDP_483-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-IMF_GDP-483">\n         [469]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">\n        U.S. dollar\n       </a>\n       is the world\'s primary\n       <a href="/wiki/Reserve_currency" title="Reserve currency">\n        reserve currency\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486">\n        <a href="#cite_note-486">\n         [472]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The U.S. economy is also the fastest growing in the Americas.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMFNorthAmericaGDP_40-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-IMFNorthAmericaGDP-40">\n         [33]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IMFSouthAmericaGDP_39-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-IMFSouthAmericaGDP-39">\n         [32]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The United States is the\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_imports" title="List of countries by imports">\n        largest importer\n       </a>\n       of goods and\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports" title="List of countries by exports">\n        second-largest exporter\n       </a>\n       , though\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_exports_per_capita" title="List of countries by exports per capita">\n        exports per capita\n       </a>\n       are relatively low. In 2010, the total\n       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_trade_of_the_United_States" title="Foreign trade of the United States">\n        U.S. trade deficit\n       </a>\n       was $635 billion.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trade_487-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Trade-487">\n         [473]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">\n        Canada\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">\n        China\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">\n        Mexico\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">\n        Japan\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">\n        Germany\n       </a>\n       are its top trading partners.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488">\n        <a href="#cite_note-488">\n         [474]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2010, oil was the largest import commodity, while transportation equipment was the country\'s largest export.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trade_487-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Trade-487">\n         [473]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Japan is the largest foreign holder of U.S. public debt.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489">\n        <a href="#cite_note-489">\n         [475]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The largest holder of the U.S. debt are American entities, including federal government accounts and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Federal_Reserve_System" title="Federal Reserve System">\n        Federal Reserve\n       </a>\n       , who hold the majority of the debt.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490">\n        <a href="#cite_note-490">\n         [476]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491">\n        <a href="#cite_note-491">\n         [477]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492">\n        <a href="#cite_note-492">\n         [478]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493">\n        <a href="#cite_note-493">\n         [479]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496">\n        <a href="#cite_note-496">\n         [fn 15]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In 2009, the private sector was estimated to constitute 86.4% of the economy, with federal government activity accounting for 4.3% and state and local government activity (including federal transfers) the remaining 9.3%.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497">\n        <a href="#cite_note-497">\n         [482]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The number of employees at all levels of government outnumber those in\n       <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing_in_the_United_States" title="Manufacturing in the United States">\n        manufacturing\n       </a>\n       by 1.7 to 1.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498">\n        <a href="#cite_note-498">\n         [483]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       While its economy has reached a\n       <a href="/wiki/Post-industrial_society" title="Post-industrial society">\n        postindustrial\n       </a>\n       level of development and its\n       <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">\n        service sector\n       </a>\n       constitutes 67.8% of GDP, the United States remains an industrial power.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Econ_499-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Econ-499">\n         [484]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The leading business field by gross business receipts is wholesale and retail trade; by net income it is manufacturing.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500">\n        <a href="#cite_note-500">\n         [485]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In the\n       <a href="/wiki/Franchising" title="Franchising">\n        franchising\n       </a>\n       business model,\n       <a href="/wiki/McDonald%27s" title="McDonald\'s">\n        McDonald\'s\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Subway_(restaurant)" title="Subway (restaurant)">\n        Subway\n       </a>\n       are the two most recognized brands in the world.\n       <a href="/wiki/Coca-Cola" title="Coca-Cola">\n        Coca-Cola\n       </a>\n       is the most recognized\n       <a href="/wiki/Soft_drink" title="Soft drink">\n        soft drink\n       </a>\n       company in the world.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501">\n        <a href="#cite_note-501">\n         [486]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Chemical products are the leading manufacturing field.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502">\n        <a href="#cite_note-502">\n         [487]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The United States is the largest producer of oil in the world, as well as its second-largest importer.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503">\n        <a href="#cite_note-503">\n         [488]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       It is the world\'s number one producer of electrical and nuclear energy, as well as\n       <a href="/wiki/Liquefied_natural_gas" title="Liquefied natural gas">\n        liquid natural gas\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Sulfur" title="Sulfur">\n        sulfur\n       </a>\n       , phosphates, and\n       <a href="/wiki/Salt" title="Salt">\n        salt\n       </a>\n       . The\n       <a href="/wiki/National_Mining_Association" title="National Mining Association">\n        National Mining Association\n       </a>\n       provides data pertaining to\n       <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">\n        coal\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Mineral" title="Mineral">\n        minerals\n       </a>\n       that include\n       <a href="/wiki/Beryllium" title="Beryllium">\n        beryllium\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">\n        copper\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">\n        lead\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Magnesium" title="Magnesium">\n        magnesium\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">\n        zinc\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Titanium" title="Titanium">\n        titanium\n       </a>\n       and others.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504">\n        <a href="#cite_note-504">\n         [489]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505">\n        <a href="#cite_note-505">\n         [490]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_the_United_States" title="Agriculture in the United States">\n        Agriculture\n       </a>\n       accounts for just under 1% of GDP,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Econ_499-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Econ-499">\n         [484]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       yet the United States is the world\'s top producer of corn\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506">\n        <a href="#cite_note-506">\n         [491]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and soybeans.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507">\n        <a href="#cite_note-507">\n         [492]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/National_Agricultural_Statistics_Service" title="National Agricultural Statistics Service">\n        National Agricultural Statistics Service\n       </a>\n       maintains agricultural statistics for products that include\n       <a href="/wiki/Peanut" title="Peanut">\n        peanuts\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Oat" title="Oat">\n        oats\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Rye" title="Rye">\n        rye\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">\n        wheat\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">\n        rice\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Cotton" title="Cotton">\n        cotton\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">\n        corn\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">\n        barley\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Hay" title="Hay">\n        hay\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Helianthus" title="Helianthus">\n        sunflowers\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Vegetable_oil" title="Vegetable oil">\n        oilseeds\n       </a>\n       . In addition, the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture" title="United States Department of Agriculture">\n        United States Department of Agriculture\n       </a>\n       (USDA) provides livestock statistics regarding\n       <a href="/wiki/Beef" title="Beef">\n        beef\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Poultry" title="Poultry">\n        poultry\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Pork" title="Pork">\n        pork\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Milk" title="Milk">\n        dairy products\n       </a>\n       . The country is the primary developer and grower of\n       <a href="/wiki/Genetically_modified_food" title="Genetically modified food">\n        genetically modified food\n       </a>\n       , representing half of the world\'s biotech\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Crops" title="Crops">\n        crops\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508">\n        <a href="#cite_note-508">\n         [493]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Consumer_spending" title="Consumer spending">\n        Consumer spending\n       </a>\n       comprises 68% of the U.S. economy in 2015.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509">\n        <a href="#cite_note-509">\n         [494]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In August 2010, the American labor force consisted of 154.1 million people. With 21.2 million people, government is the leading field of employment. The largest private employment sector is health care and social assistance, with 16.4 million people. About 12% of workers are\n       <a href="/wiki/Labor_unions_in_the_United_States" title="Labor unions in the United States">\n        unionized\n       </a>\n       , compared to 30% in\n       <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">\n        Western Europe\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510">\n        <a href="#cite_note-510">\n         [495]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The World Bank ranks the United States first in the ease of hiring and firing workers.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EDBI_511-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-EDBI-511">\n         [496]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The United States is ranked among the top three in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Global_Competitiveness_Report" title="Global Competitiveness Report">\n        Global Competitiveness Report\n       </a>\n       as well. It has a smaller\n       <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">\n        welfare state\n       </a>\n       and redistributes less income through government action than European nations tend to.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512">\n        <a href="#cite_note-512">\n         [497]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The United States is the only advanced economy that does not\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_statutory_minimum_employment_leave_by_country" title="List of statutory minimum employment leave by country">\n        guarantee its workers paid vacation\n       </a>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513">\n        <a href="#cite_note-513">\n         [498]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and is one of just a few countries in the world without\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paid_family_leave" title="Paid family leave">\n        paid family leave\n       </a>\n       as a legal right, with the others being\n       <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">\n        Papua New Guinea\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Suriname" title="Suriname">\n        Suriname\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">\n        Liberia\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514">\n        <a href="#cite_note-514">\n         [499]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       While federal law currently does not require sick leave, it is a common benefit for government workers and full-time employees at corporations.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SLCNN_515-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-SLCNN-515">\n         [500]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       74% of full-time American workers get paid sick leave, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, although only 24% of part-time workers get the same benefits.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SLCNN_515-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-SLCNN-515">\n         [500]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2009, the United States had the third-highest\n       <a href="/wiki/Workforce_productivity" title="Workforce productivity">\n        workforce productivity\n       </a>\n       per person in the world, behind\n       <a href="/wiki/Luxembourg" title="Luxembourg">\n        Luxembourg\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">\n        Norway\n       </a>\n       . It was fourth in productivity per hour, behind those two countries and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">\n        Netherlands\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516">\n        <a href="#cite_note-516">\n         [501]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">\n        2008\xe2\x80\x932012 global recession\n       </a>\n       significantly affected the United States, with output still below potential according to the\n       <a href="/wiki/Congressional_Budget_Office" title="Congressional Budget Office">\n        Congressional Budget Office\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517">\n        <a href="#cite_note-517">\n         [502]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       It brought high\n       <a href="/wiki/Unemployment" title="Unemployment">\n        unemployment\n       </a>\n       (which has been decreasing but remains above pre-recession levels), along with low\n       <a href="/wiki/Consumer_confidence_index" title="Consumer confidence index">\n        consumer confidence\n       </a>\n       , the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_housing_bubble" title="United States housing bubble">\n        continuing decline in home values and increase in foreclosures and personal bankruptcies\n       </a>\n       , an escalating federal debt crisis,\n       <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">\n        inflation\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/2000s_energy_crisis" title="2000s energy crisis">\n        rising petroleum and food prices\n       </a>\n       .\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span id="Income,_poverty_and_wealth">\n       </span>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Income.2C_poverty_and_wealth">\n        Income, poverty and wealth\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:South_San_Jose_(crop).jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1314" data-file-width="2048" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/South_San_Jose_%28crop%29.jpg/220px-South_San_Jose_%28crop%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/South_San_Jose_%28crop%29.jpg/330px-South_San_Jose_%28crop%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/South_San_Jose_%28crop%29.jpg/440px-South_San_Jose_%28crop%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:South_San_Jose_(crop).jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         A\n         <a href="/wiki/Tract_housing" title="Tract housing">\n          tract housing\n         </a>\n         development in\n         <a href="/wiki/San_Jose,_California" title="San Jose, California">\n          San Jose, California\n         </a>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Further information:\n       <a href="/wiki/Income_in_the_United_States" title="Income in the United States">\n        Income in the United States\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_the_United_States" title="Poverty in the United States">\n        Poverty in the United States\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Affluence_in_the_United_States" title="Affluence in the United States">\n        Affluence in the United States\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_counties_by_per_capita_income" title="United States counties by per capita income">\n        United States counties by per capita income\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Income_inequality_in_the_United_States" title="Income inequality in the United States">\n        Income inequality in the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Americans have the highest average\n       <a href="/wiki/Household_income" title="Household income">\n        household\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_average_wage" title="List of countries by average wage">\n        employee\n       </a>\n       income among OECD nations, and in 2007 had the second-highest\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Median_household_income" title="Median household income">\n        median household income\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Household_Income_518-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Household_Income-518">\n         [503]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519">\n        <a href="#cite_note-519">\n         [504]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_520-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-520">\n         [505]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       According to the Census Bureau, median household income was $59,039 in 2016.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521">\n        <a href="#cite_note-521">\n         [506]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Accounting for 4.4% of the global population, Americans collectively possess 41.6% of the world\'s total wealth,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522">\n        <a href="#cite_note-522">\n         [507]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and Americans make up roughly half of the world\'s population of millionaires.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523">\n        <a href="#cite_note-523">\n         [508]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_Food_Security_Index" title="Global Food Security Index">\n        Global Food Security Index\n       </a>\n       ranked the U.S. number one for food affordability and overall food security in March 2013.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524">\n        <a href="#cite_note-524">\n         [509]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Americans on average have over twice as much living space per dwelling and per person as\n       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">\n        European Union\n       </a>\n       residents, and more than every EU nation.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Heritage_Poor_525-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Heritage_Poor-525">\n         [510]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       For 2013 the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Development_Programme" title="United Nations Development Programme">\n        United Nations Development Programme\n       </a>\n       ranked the United States 5th among 187 countries in its\n       <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index#2014_report" title="Human Development Index">\n        Human Development Index\n       </a>\n       and 28th in its\n       <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index#Inequality-adjusted_HDI" title="Human Development Index">\n        inequality-adjusted HDI\n       </a>\n       (IHDI).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526">\n        <a href="#cite_note-526">\n         [511]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       After years of stagnant growth, in 2016, according to the Census, median household income reached a record high after two consecutive years of record growth, although income inequality remains at record highs with top fifth of earners taking home more than half of all overall income.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527">\n        <a href="#cite_note-527">\n         [512]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       There has been a widening gap between productivity and median incomes since the 1970s.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528">\n        <a href="#cite_note-528">\n         [513]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       However, the gap between total compensation and productivity is not as wide because of increased employee benefits such as health insurance.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529">\n        <a href="#cite_note-529">\n         [514]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The rise in the share of total annual income received by the top 1 percent, which has more than doubled from 9 percent in 1976 to 20 percent in 2011, has significantly affected\n       <a href="/wiki/Income_inequality_in_the_United_States" title="Income inequality in the United States">\n        income inequality\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PikettySaez_530-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-PikettySaez-530">\n         [515]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       leaving the United States with one of the widest income distributions among OECD nations.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sme_531-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Sme-531">\n         [516]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Upper_class" title="Upper class">\n        top 1 percent of income-earners\n       </a>\n       accounted for 52 percent of the income gains from 2009 to 2015, where income is defined as market income excluding government transfers,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532">\n        <a href="#cite_note-532">\n         [517]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The extent and relevance of income inequality is a matter of debate.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533">\n        <a href="#cite_note-533">\n         [518]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">\n        [\n        <i>\n         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Disputed statement">\n          <span title="This claim has reliable sources with contradicting facts (April 2015)">\n           disputed\n          </span>\n         </a>\n         <span class="metadata">\n          \xe2\x80\x93\n          <a href="/wiki/Talk:United_States#Trends_in_local_vs_global_inequality" title="Talk:United States">\n           discuss\n          </a>\n         </span>\n        </i>\n        ]\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534">\n        <a href="#cite_note-534">\n         [519]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <table class="floatright" style="margin:auto; text-align:right;">\n       <caption>\n        <b>\n         United States\' families median net worth\n        </b>\n       </caption>\n       <caption align="bottom" style="caption-side: bottom; text-align: right;">\n        source: Fed Survey of Consumer Finances\n        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535">\n         <a href="#cite_note-535">\n          [520]\n         </a>\n        </sup>\n       </caption>\n       <tr>\n        <th>\n         in 2013 dollars\n        </th>\n        <th>\n         1998\n        </th>\n        <th>\n         2013\n        </th>\n        <th>\n         change\n        </th>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         All families\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $102,500\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $81,200\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         -20.8%\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         Bottom 20% of incomes\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $8,300\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $6,100\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         -26.5%\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         2nd lowest 20% of incomes\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $47,400\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $22,400\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         -52.7%\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         Middle 20% of incomes\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $76,300\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $61,700\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         -19.1%\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n       <tr>\n        <td>\n         Top 10%\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $646,600\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         $1,130,700\n        </td>\n        <td>\n         +74.9%\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n      </table>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Wealth_in_the_United_States" title="Wealth in the United States">\n        Wealth\n       </a>\n       , like income and taxes, is\n       <a href="/wiki/Wealth_inequality_in_the_United_States" title="Wealth inequality in the United States">\n        highly concentrated\n       </a>\n       ; the richest 10% of the adult population possess 72% of the country\'s household wealth, while the bottom half claim only 2%.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536">\n        <a href="#cite_note-536">\n         [521]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       According to a September 2017 report by the Federal Reserve, the top 1% controlled 38.6% of the country\'s wealth in 2016.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537">\n        <a href="#cite_note-537">\n         [522]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Between June 2007 and November 2008 the\n       <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">\n        global recession\n       </a>\n       led to falling asset prices around the world. Assets owned by Americans lost about a quarter of their value.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538">\n        <a href="#cite_note-538">\n         [523]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Since peaking in the second quarter of 2007, household wealth was down $14\xc2\xa0trillion, but has since increased $14\xc2\xa0trillion over 2006 levels.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539">\n        <a href="#cite_note-539">\n         [524]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-540">\n        <a href="#cite_note-540">\n         [525]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       At the end of 2014,\n       <a href="/wiki/Household_debt" title="Household debt">\n        household debt\n       </a>\n       amounted to $11.8\xc2\xa0trillion,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541">\n        <a href="#cite_note-541">\n         [526]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       down from $13.8\xc2\xa0trillion at the end of 2008.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542">\n        <a href="#cite_note-542">\n         [527]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       There were about 578,424 sheltered and unsheltered\n       <a href="/wiki/Homelessness_in_the_United_States" title="Homelessness in the United States">\n        homeless persons in the U.S.\n       </a>\n       in January 2014, with almost two-thirds staying in an emergency shelter or transitional housing program.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543">\n        <a href="#cite_note-543">\n         [528]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2011\n       <a href="/wiki/Hunger_in_the_United_States#Children" title="Hunger in the United States">\n        16.7 million children lived in food-insecure households\n       </a>\n       , about 35% more than 2007 levels, though only 1.1% of U.S. children, or 845,000, saw reduced food intake or disrupted eating patterns at some point during the year, and most cases were not chronic.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544">\n        <a href="#cite_note-544">\n         [529]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       According to a 2014 report by the Census Bureau, one in five young adults lives in\n       <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_the_United_States" title="Poverty in the United States">\n        poverty\n       </a>\n       today, up from one
