in seven in 1980.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545">\n        <a href="#cite_note-545">\n         [530]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">\n        Infrastructure\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">\n        Transportation\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_the_United_States" title="Transportation in the United States">\n        Transportation in the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_current_Interstates.svg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="432" data-file-width="689" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Map_of_current_Interstates.svg/220px-Map_of_current_Interstates.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Map_of_current_Interstates.svg/330px-Map_of_current_Interstates.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Map_of_current_Interstates.svg/440px-Map_of_current_Interstates.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_current_Interstates.svg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The\n         <a href="/wiki/Interstate_Highway_System" title="Interstate Highway System">\n          Interstate Highway System\n         </a>\n         , which extends 46,876 miles (75,440\xc2\xa0km).\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546">\n          <a href="#cite_note-546">\n           [531]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Personal transportation is dominated by automobiles, which operate on a network of 4 million miles (6.4 million km) of public roads,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547">\n        <a href="#cite_note-547">\n         [532]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       including one of the world\'s\n       <a href="/wiki/National_Highway_System_(United_States)" title="National Highway System (United States)">\n        longest highway systems\n       </a>\n       at 57,000 miles (91700\xc2\xa0km).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548">\n        <a href="#cite_note-548">\n         [533]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The world\'s second-largest automobile market,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549">\n        <a href="#cite_note-549">\n         [534]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       the United States has the highest rate of per-capita vehicle ownership in the world, with 765 vehicles per 1,000 Americans.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550">\n        <a href="#cite_note-550">\n         [535]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       About 40% of\n       <a href="/wiki/Passenger_vehicles_in_the_United_States" title="Passenger vehicles in the United States">\n        personal vehicles\n       </a>\n       are vans,\n       <a href="/wiki/Sport_utility_vehicle" title="Sport utility vehicle">\n        SUVs\n       </a>\n       , or light trucks.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551">\n        <a href="#cite_note-551">\n         [536]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The average American adult (accounting for all drivers and non-drivers) spends 55 minutes driving every day, traveling 29 miles (47\xc2\xa0km).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552">\n        <a href="#cite_note-552">\n         [537]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tleft">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="959" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg/220px-High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg/330px-High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg/440px-High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:High_Speed_Railroad_Map_of_the_United_States_2013.svg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Map showing current\n         <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_the_United_States" title="High-speed rail in the United States">\n          rail speeds\n         </a>\n         in the United States.\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553">\n          <a href="#cite_note-553">\n           [538]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Mass_transit_in_the_United_States" title="Mass transit in the United States">\n        Mass transit accounts for 9% of total U.S. work trips\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554">\n        <a href="#cite_note-554">\n         [539]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555">\n        <a href="#cite_note-555">\n         [540]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/Rail_transportation_in_the_United_States" title="Rail transportation in the United States">\n        Transport of goods by rail\n       </a>\n       is extensive, though relatively low numbers of passengers (approximately 31 million annually) use intercity rail to travel, partly because of the low population density throughout much of the U.S. interior.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556">\n        <a href="#cite_note-556">\n         [541]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557">\n        <a href="#cite_note-557">\n         [542]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       However, ridership on\n       <a href="/wiki/Amtrak" title="Amtrak">\n        Amtrak\n       </a>\n       , the national intercity passenger\n       <a href="/wiki/Rail_transportation_in_the_United_States" title="Rail transportation in the United States">\n        rail system\n       </a>\n       , grew by almost 37% between 2000 and 2010.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558">\n        <a href="#cite_note-558">\n         [543]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Also,\n       <a href="/wiki/Light_rail_in_the_United_States" title="Light rail in the United States">\n        light rail development\n       </a>\n       has increased in recent years.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559">\n        <a href="#cite_note-559">\n         [544]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Bicycle usage for work commutes is minimal.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560">\n        <a href="#cite_note-560">\n         [545]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_airlines_of_the_United_States" title="List of airlines of the United States">\n        civil airline industry\n       </a>\n       is entirely privately owned and has been largely\n       <a href="/wiki/Airline_Deregulation_Act" title="Airline Deregulation Act">\n        deregulated since 1978\n       </a>\n       , while\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_the_United_States" title="List of airports in the United States">\n        most major airports\n       </a>\n       are publicly owned.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561">\n        <a href="#cite_note-561">\n         [546]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The three largest airlines in the world by passengers carried are U.S.-based;\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Airlines" title="American Airlines">\n        American Airlines\n       </a>\n       is number one after its 2013 acquisition by\n       <a href="/wiki/US_Airways" title="US Airways">\n        US Airways\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-562">\n        <a href="#cite_note-562">\n         [547]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Of the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_the_world%27s_busiest_airports_by_passenger_traffic" title="List of the world\'s busiest airports by passenger traffic">\n        world\'s 50 busiest passenger airports\n       </a>\n       , 16 are in the United States, including the busiest,\n       <a href="/wiki/Hartsfield%E2%80%93Jackson_Atlanta_International_Airport" title="Hartsfield\xe2\x80\x93Jackson Atlanta International Airport">\n        Hartsfield\xe2\x80\x93Jackson Atlanta International Airport\n       </a>\n       , and the fourth-busiest,\n       <a href="/wiki/O%27Hare_International_Airport" title="O\'Hare International Airport">\n        O\'Hare International Airport\n       </a>\n       in\n       <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">\n        Chicago\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-563">\n        <a href="#cite_note-563">\n         [548]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In the aftermath of the\n       <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">\n        9/11 attacks\n       </a>\n       of 2001, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Transportation_Security_Administration" title="Transportation Security Administration">\n        Transportation Security Administration\n       </a>\n       was created to police airports and commercial airliners.\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">\n        Energy\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Further information:\n       <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_the_United_States" title="Energy policy of the United States">\n        Energy policy of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="808" data-file-width="1233" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg/220px-UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg/330px-UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg/440px-UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UnitedStatesPowerGrid.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The U.S. power transmission grid consists of about 300,000\xc2\xa0km (190,000\xc2\xa0mi) of lines operated by approximately 500 companies. The\n         <a href="/wiki/North_American_Electric_Reliability_Corporation" title="North American Electric Reliability Corporation">\n          North American Electric Reliability Corporation\n         </a>\n         (NERC) oversees all of them.\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_the_United_States" title="Energy in the United States">\n        United States energy\n       </a>\n       market is about 29,000\n       <a href="/wiki/Kilowatt_hour" title="Kilowatt hour">\n        terawatt hours\n       </a>\n       per year.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IEA2013_564-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-IEA2013-564">\n         [549]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_energy_consumption_per_capita" title="List of countries by energy consumption per capita">\n        Energy consumption per capita\n       </a>\n       is 7.8\xc2\xa0tons (7076\xc2\xa0kg) of oil equivalent per year, the 10th-highest rate in the world. In 2005, 40% of this energy came from petroleum, 23% from coal, and 22% from natural gas. The remainder was supplied by nuclear power and\n       <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">\n        renewable energy\n       </a>\n       sources.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-565">\n        <a href="#cite_note-565">\n         [550]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The United States is the world\'s largest consumer of petroleum.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-566">\n        <a href="#cite_note-566">\n         [551]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The United States has 27% of global coal reserves.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BPReview_567-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-BPReview-567">\n         [552]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       It is the world\'s largest producer of natural gas and crude oil.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568">\n        <a href="#cite_note-568">\n         [553]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       For decades,\n       <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_the_United_States" title="Nuclear power in the United States">\n        nuclear power\n       </a>\n       has played a limited role relative to many other developed countries, in part because of public perception in the wake of a\n       <a href="/wiki/Three_Mile_Island_accident" title="Three Mile Island accident">\n        1979 accident\n       </a>\n       . In 2007, several applications for new nuclear plants were filed.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-569">\n        <a href="#cite_note-569">\n         [554]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">\n        Water supply and sanitation\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Drinking_water_supply_and_sanitation_in_the_United_States" title="Drinking water supply and sanitation in the United States">\n        Drinking water supply and sanitation in the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Issues that affect water supply in the United States include droughts in the West,\n       <a href="/wiki/Water_scarcity" title="Water scarcity">\n        water scarcity\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Water_pollution_in_the_United_States" title="Water pollution in the United States">\n        pollution\n       </a>\n       , a backlog of investment, concerns about the affordability of water for the poorest, and a rapidly retiring workforce. Increased variability and intensity of rainfall as a result of\n       <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">\n        climate change\n       </a>\n       is expected to produce both more severe droughts and flooding, with potentially serious consequences for water supply and for pollution from\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Combined_sewer_overflow" title="Combined sewer overflow">\n        combined sewer overflows\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AMWA_570-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-AMWA-570">\n         [555]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-National_Academies_571-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-National_Academies-571">\n         [556]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-574">\n        <a href="#cite_note-574">\n         [fn 16]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">\n        Education\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_United_States" title="Education in the United States">\n        Education in the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1906" data-file-width="2902" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg/220px-University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg/330px-University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg/440px-University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:University-of-Virginia-Rotunda.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The\n         <a href="/wiki/University_of_Virginia" title="University of Virginia">\n          University of Virginia\n         </a>\n         , founded by\n         <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">\n          Thomas Jefferson\n         </a>\n         in 1819, is one of the many public universities in the United States. Universal government-funded education exists in the United States, while there are also many privately funded institutions.\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       American\n       <a href="/wiki/State_school" title="State school">\n        public education\n       </a>\n       is operated by state and local governments, regulated by the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Education" title="United States Department of Education">\n        United States Department of Education\n       </a>\n       through restrictions on federal grants. In most states, children are required to attend school from the age of six or seven (generally,\n       <a href="/wiki/Kindergarten" title="Kindergarten">\n        kindergarten\n       </a>\n       or\n       <a href="/wiki/First_grade" title="First grade">\n        first grade\n       </a>\n       ) until they turn 18 (generally bringing them through\n       <a href="/wiki/Twelfth_grade" title="Twelfth grade">\n        twelfth grade\n       </a>\n       , the end of\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High_school" title="High school">\n        high school\n       </a>\n       ); some states allow students to leave school at 16 or 17.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-575">\n        <a href="#cite_note-575">\n         [559]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       About 12% of children are enrolled in\n       <a href="/wiki/Parochial_school" title="Parochial school">\n        parochial\n       </a>\n       or\n       <a href="/wiki/Nonsectarian" title="Nonsectarian">\n        nonsectarian\n       </a>\n       <a href="/wiki/Private_school" title="Private school">\n        private schools\n       </a>\n       . Just over 2% of children are\n       <a href="/wiki/Homeschooling" title="Homeschooling">\n        homeschooled\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-576">\n        <a href="#cite_note-576">\n         [560]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The U.S. spends more on education per student than any nation in the world, spending more than $11,000 per elementary student in 2010 and more than $12,000 per high school student.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-education_spending_577-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-education_spending-577">\n         [561]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Some 80% of U.S. college students attend\n       <a href="/wiki/Public_university" title="Public university">\n        public universities\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-578">\n        <a href="#cite_note-578">\n         [562]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The United States has many competitive private and public\n       <a href="/wiki/Lists_of_American_institutions_of_higher_education" title="Lists of American institutions of higher education">\n        institutions of higher education\n       </a>\n       . The majority of the world\'s top universities listed by different ranking organizations are in the U.S.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-579">\n        <a href="#cite_note-579">\n         [563]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-580">\n        <a href="#cite_note-580">\n         [564]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-581">\n        <a href="#cite_note-581">\n         [565]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       There are also local\n       <a href="/wiki/Community_college" title="Community college">\n        community colleges\n       </a>\n       with generally more open admission policies, shorter academic programs, and lower tuition. Of Americans 25 and older, 84.6% graduated from high school, 52.6% attended some college, 27.2% earned a\n       <a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor\'s degree">\n        bachelor\'s degree\n       </a>\n       , and 9.6% earned graduate degrees.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582">\n        <a href="#cite_note-582">\n         [566]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The basic\n       <a href="/wiki/Literacy" title="Literacy">\n        literacy\n       </a>\n       rate is approximately 99%.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WF_235-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-WF-235">\n         [225]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583">\n        <a href="#cite_note-583">\n         [567]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The United Nations assigns the United States an Education Index of 0.97, tying it for 12th in the world.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584">\n        <a href="#cite_note-584">\n         [568]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       As for public expenditures on higher education, the U.S. trails some other\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">\n        OECD\n       </a>\n       nations but spends more per student than the OECD average, and more than all nations in combined public and private spending.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-education_spending_577-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-education_spending-577">\n         [561]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585">\n        <a href="#cite_note-585">\n         [569]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       As of 2012\n       <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">\n        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit">\n         [update]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Student_debt" title="Student debt">\n        student loan debt\n       </a>\n       exceeded one trillion dollars, more than Americans owe on credit cards.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586">\n        <a href="#cite_note-586">\n         [570]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">\n        Culture\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States" title="Culture of the United States">\n        Culture of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       See also:\n       <a href="/wiki/Alaska_Natives#Cultures" title="Alaska Natives">\n        Alaska Natives \xc2\xa7\xc2\xa0Cultures\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Native_American_cultures_in_the_United_States" title="Native American cultures in the United States">\n        Native American cultures in the United States\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_Native_Hawaiians" title="Culture of the Native Hawaiians">\n        Culture of the Native Hawaiians\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Social_class_in_the_United_States" title="Social class in the United States">\n        Social class in the United States\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_the_United_States" title="Public holidays in the United States">\n        Public holidays in the United States\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_the_United_States" title="Tourism in the United States">\n        Tourism in the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The United States is home to\n       <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">\n        many cultures\n       </a>\n       and a wide variety of ethnic groups, traditions, and values.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DD_587-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-DD-587">\n         [571]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Society_in_Focus_588-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Society_in_Focus-588">\n         [572]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Aside from the\n       <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">\n        Native American\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Native_Hawaiians" title="Native Hawaiians">\n        Native Hawaiian\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Alaska_Natives" title="Alaska Natives">\n        Native Alaskan\n       </a>\n       populations, nearly all Americans or their ancestors settled or immigrated within the past five centuries.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-589">\n        <a href="#cite_note-589">\n         [573]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Mainstream American culture is a\n       <a href="/wiki/Western_culture" title="Western culture">\n        Western culture\n       </a>\n       largely derived from the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_American" title="European American">\n        traditions of European immigrants\n       </a>\n       with influences from many other sources, such as\n       <a href="/wiki/African-American_culture" title="African-American culture">\n        traditions brought by slaves from Africa\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DD_587-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-DD-587">\n         [571]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-590">\n        <a href="#cite_note-590">\n         [574]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       More recent immigration from\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_American" title="Asian American">\n        Asia\n       </a>\n       and especially\n       <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_culture" title="Latin American culture">\n        Latin America\n       </a>\n       has added to a cultural mix that has been described as both a homogenizing\n       <a href="/wiki/Melting_pot" title="Melting pot">\n        melting pot\n       </a>\n       , and a heterogeneous\n       <a href="/wiki/Salad_bowl_(cultural_idea)" title="Salad bowl (cultural idea)">\n        salad bowl\n       </a>\n       in which immigrants and their descendants retain distinctive cultural characteristics.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DD_587-2">\n        <a href="#cite_note-DD-587">\n         [571]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Core American culture was established by\n       <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">\n        Protestant\n       </a>\n       British colonists and shaped by the\n       <a href="/wiki/Frontier" title="Frontier">\n        frontier\n       </a>\n       settlement process, with the traits derived passed down to descendants and transmitted to immigrants through assimilation. Americans have traditionally been characterized by a strong\n       <a href="/wiki/Work_ethic" title="Work ethic">\n        work ethic\n       </a>\n       , competitiveness, and individualism,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-591">\n        <a href="#cite_note-591">\n         [575]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       as well as a unifying belief in an "American\n       <a href="/wiki/Creed" title="Creed">\n        creed\n       </a>\n       " emphasizing liberty, equality, private property, democracy, rule of law, and a preference for limited government.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592">\n        <a href="#cite_note-592">\n         [576]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Americans are extremely charitable by global standards. According to a 2006 British study, Americans gave 1.67% of GDP to charity, more than any other nation studied, more than twice the second place British figure of 0.73%, and around twelve times the French figure of 0.14%.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-593">\n        <a href="#cite_note-593">\n         [577]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-594">\n        <a href="#cite_note-594">\n         [578]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Dream" title="American Dream">\n        American Dream\n       </a>\n       , or the perception that Americans enjoy high\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socio-economic_mobility_in_the_United_States" title="Socio-economic mobility in the United States">\n        social mobility\n       </a>\n       , plays a key role in attracting immigrants.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-595">\n        <a href="#cite_note-595">\n         [579]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Whether this perception is realistic has been a topic of debate.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-socialmobility_596-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-socialmobility-596">\n         [580]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-597">\n        <a href="#cite_note-597">\n         [581]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CAP_598-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-CAP-598">\n         [582]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schneider_599-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Schneider-599">\n         [583]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hagopian_485-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Hagopian-485">\n         [471]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-600">\n        <a href="#cite_note-600">\n         [584]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       While mainstream culture holds that the United States is a\n       <a href="/wiki/Classless_society" title="Classless society">\n        classless society\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-601">\n        <a href="#cite_note-601">\n         [585]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       scholars identify significant differences between the country\'s social classes, affecting\n       <a href="/wiki/Socialization" title="Socialization">\n        socialization\n       </a>\n       , language, and values.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-602">\n        <a href="#cite_note-602">\n         [586]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Americans\' self-images, social viewpoints, and cultural expectations are associated with their occupations to an unusually close degree.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-603">\n        <a href="#cite_note-603">\n         [587]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       While Americans tend greatly to value socioeconomic achievement, being\n       <a href="/wiki/Average_Joe" title="Average Joe">\n        ordinary or average\n       </a>\n       is generally seen as a positive attribute.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-604">\n        <a href="#cite_note-604">\n         [588]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Food">\n        Food\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_the_United_States" title="Cuisine of the United States">\n        Cuisine of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1802" data-file-width="2700" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg/220px-Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg/330px-Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg/440px-Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Motherhood_and_apple_pie.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <a href="/wiki/Apple_pie" title="Apple pie">\n          Apple pie\n         </a>\n         is a food commonly associated with American cuisine.\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Mainstream American cuisine is similar to that in other Western countries.\n       <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">\n        Wheat\n       </a>\n       is the primary cereal grain with about three-quarters of grain products made of wheat flour\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wheat_605-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Wheat-605">\n         [589]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and many dishes use indigenous ingredients, such as turkey, venison, potatoes, sweet potatoes, corn, squash, and maple syrup which were consumed by Native Americans and early European settlers.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606">\n        <a href="#cite_note-606">\n         [590]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       These home grown foods are part of a shared national menu on one of America\'s most popular holidays;\n       <a href="/wiki/Thanksgiving_(United_States)" title="Thanksgiving (United States)">\n        Thanksgiving\n       </a>\n       , when some Americans make traditional foods to celebrate the occasion.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mintz1996_607-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Mintz1996-607">\n         [591]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Roast_turkey.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3216" data-file-width="4288" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Roast_turkey.jpg/220px-Roast_turkey.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Roast_turkey.jpg/330px-Roast_turkey.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Roast_turkey.jpg/440px-Roast_turkey.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Roast_turkey.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Roasted\n         <a href="/wiki/Turkey_(bird)" title="Turkey (bird)">\n          turkey\n         </a>\n         is a traditional menu item of an American\n         <a href="/wiki/Thanksgiving_(United_States)" title="Thanksgiving (United States)">\n          Thanksgiving\n         </a>\n         dinner.\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GillespieMechling1995_608-0">\n          <a href="#cite_note-GillespieMechling1995-608">\n           [592]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       Characteristic dishes such as apple pie, fried chicken, pizza, hamburgers, and hot dogs derive from the recipes of various immigrants. French fries,\n       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_cuisine" title="Mexican cuisine">\n        Mexican\n       </a>\n       dishes such as burritos and tacos, and pasta dishes freely adapted from\n       <a href="/wiki/Italian_cuisine" title="Italian cuisine">\n        Italian\n       </a>\n       sources are widely consumed.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IFT_609-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-IFT-609">\n         [593]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Americans drink three times as much coffee as tea.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-coffeeandtea_610-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-coffeeandtea-610">\n         [594]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Marketing by U.S. industries is largely responsible for making orange juice and milk ubiquitous\n       <a href="/wiki/Breakfast" title="Breakfast">\n        breakfast\n       </a>\n       beverages.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-611">\n        <a href="#cite_note-611">\n         [595]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-612">\n        <a href="#cite_note-612">\n         [596]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       American eating habits owe a great deal to that of their\n       <a href="/wiki/British_cuisine" title="British cuisine">\n        British culinary\n       </a>\n       roots with some variations. Although American lands could grow newer vegetables that Britain could not, most colonists would not eat these new foods until accepted by Europeans.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Levenstein1988_613-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Levenstein1988-613">\n         [597]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Over time American foods changed to a point that food critic,\n       <a href="/wiki/John_L._Hess" title="John L. Hess">\n        John L. Hess\n       </a>\n       stated in 1972:\n       <i>\n        "Our founding fathers were as far superior to our present political leaders in the quality of their food as they were in the quality of their prose and intelligence"\n       </i>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wallach2013_614-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Wallach2013-614">\n         [598]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The American\n       <a href="/wiki/Fast_food" title="Fast food">\n        fast food\n       </a>\n       industry, the world\'s largest,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-615">\n        <a href="#cite_note-615">\n         [599]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       pioneered the\n       <a href="/wiki/Drive-through" title="Drive-through">\n        drive-through\n       </a>\n       format in the 1940s.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drivethru_616-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-drivethru-616">\n         [600]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Fast food consumption has sparked health concerns. During the 1980s and 1990s, Americans\' caloric intake rose 24%;\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IFT_609-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-IFT-609">\n         [593]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       frequent dining at fast food outlets is associated with what public health officials call the American "\n       <a href="/wiki/Obesity_in_the_United_States" title="Obesity in the United States">\n        obesity epidemic\n       </a>\n       ".\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-617">\n        <a href="#cite_note-617">\n         [601]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Highly sweetened soft drinks are widely popular, and sugared beverages account for nine percent of American caloric intake.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-618">\n        <a href="#cite_note-618">\n         [602]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span id="Literature,_philosophy,_and_the_arts">\n       </span>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature.2C_philosophy.2C_and_the_arts">\n        Literature, philosophy, and the arts\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main articles:\n       <a href="/wiki/American_literature" title="American literature">\n        American literature\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/American_philosophy" title="American philosophy">\n        American philosophy\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_the_United_States" title="Architecture of the United States">\n        Architecture of the United States\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Visual_art_of_the_United_States" title="Visual art of the United States">\n        Visual art of the United States\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/American_classical_music" title="American classical music">\n        American classical music\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tleft">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mark_Twain,_Brady-Handy_photo_portrait,_Feb_7,_1871,_cropped.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="818" data-file-width="521" height="267" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Mark_Twain%2C_Brady-Handy_photo_portrait%2C_Feb_7%2C_1871%2C_cropped.jpg/170px-Mark_Twain%2C_Brady-Handy_photo_portrait%2C_Feb_7%2C_1871%2C_cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Mark_Twain%2C_Brady-Handy_photo_portrait%2C_Feb_7%2C_1871%2C_cropped.jpg/255px-Mark_Twain%2C_Brady-Handy_photo_portrait%2C_Feb_7%2C_1871%2C_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Mark_Twain%2C_Brady-Handy_photo_portrait%2C_Feb_7%2C_1871%2C_cropped.jpg/340px-Mark_Twain%2C_Brady-Handy_photo_portrait%2C_Feb_7%2C_1871%2C_cropped.jpg 2x" width="170"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mark_Twain,_Brady-Handy_photo_portrait,_Feb_7,_1871,_cropped.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <a href="/wiki/Mark_Twain" title="Mark Twain">\n          Mark Twain\n         </a>\n         , American author and\n         <a href="/wiki/Comedy" title="Comedy">\n          humorist\n         </a>\n         .\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       In the 18th and early 19th centuries, American art and literature took most of its cues from Europe. Writers such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Nathaniel_Hawthorne" title="Nathaniel Hawthorne">\n        Nathaniel Hawthorne\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Allan_Poe" title="Edgar Allan Poe">\n        Edgar Allan Poe\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Henry_David_Thoreau" title="Henry David Thoreau">\n        Henry David Thoreau\n       </a>\n       established a distinctive American literary voice by the middle of the 19th century.\n       <a href="/wiki/Mark_Twain" title="Mark Twain">\n        Mark Twain\n       </a>\n       and poet\n       <a href="/wiki/Walt_Whitman" title="Walt Whitman">\n        Walt Whitman\n       </a>\n       were major figures in the century\'s second half;\n       <a href="/wiki/Emily_Dickinson" title="Emily Dickinson">\n        Emily Dickinson\n       </a>\n       , virtually unknown during her lifetime, is now recognized as an essential American poet.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-619">\n        <a href="#cite_note-619">\n         [603]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       A work seen as capturing fundamental aspects of the national experience and character\xe2\x80\x94such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Herman_Melville" title="Herman Melville">\n        Herman Melville\n       </a>\n       \'s\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Moby-Dick" title="Moby-Dick">\n         Moby-Dick\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1851), Twain\'s\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Adventures_of_Huckleberry_Finn" title="Adventures of Huckleberry Finn">\n         The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1885),\n       <a href="/wiki/F._Scott_Fitzgerald" title="F. Scott Fitzgerald">\n        F. Scott Fitzgerald\n       </a>\n       \'s\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/The_Great_Gatsby" title="The Great Gatsby">\n         The Great Gatsby\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1925) and\n       <a href="/wiki/Harper_Lee" title="Harper Lee">\n        Harper Lee\n       </a>\n       \'s\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/To_Kill_a_Mockingbird" title="To Kill a Mockingbird">\n         To Kill a Mockingbird\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1960)\xe2\x80\x94may be dubbed the "\n       <a href="/wiki/Great_American_Novel" title="Great American Novel">\n        Great American Novel\n       </a>\n       ".\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-620">\n        <a href="#cite_note-620">\n         [604]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Twelve U.S. citizens have won the\n       <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">\n        Nobel Prize in Literature\n       </a>\n       , most recently\n       <a href="/wiki/Bob_Dylan" title="Bob Dylan">\n        Bob Dylan\n       </a>\n       in 2016.\n       <a href="/wiki/William_Faulkner" title="William Faulkner">\n        William Faulkner\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Ernest_Hemingway" title="Ernest Hemingway">\n        Ernest Hemingway\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/John_Steinbeck" title="John Steinbeck">\n        John Steinbeck\n       </a>\n       are often named among the most influential writers of the 20th century.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-621">\n        <a href="#cite_note-621">\n         [605]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Popular literary genres such as the\n       <a href="/wiki/Western_fiction" title="Western fiction">\n        Western\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Hardboiled" title="Hardboiled">\n        hardboiled\n       </a>\n       crime fiction developed in the United States. The\n       <a href="/wiki/Beat_Generation" title="Beat Generation">\n        Beat Generation\n       </a>\n       writers opened up new literary approaches, as have\n       <a href="/wiki/Postmodern_literature" title="Postmodern literature">\n        postmodernist\n       </a>\n       authors such as\n       <a href="/wiki/John_Barth" title="John Barth">\n        John Barth\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Pynchon" title="Thomas Pynchon">\n        Thomas Pynchon\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Don_DeLillo" title="Don DeLillo">\n        Don DeLillo\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lesher2000_622-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Lesher2000-622">\n         [606]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Transcendentalism" title="Transcendentalism">\n        transcendentalists\n       </a>\n       , led by Thoreau and\n       <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Waldo_Emerson" title="Ralph Waldo Emerson">\n        Ralph Waldo Emerson\n       </a>\n       , established the first major\n       <a href="/wiki/American_philosophy" title="American philosophy">\n        American philosophical movement\n       </a>\n       . After the Civil War,\n       <a href="/wiki/Charles_Sanders_Peirce" title="Charles Sanders Peirce">\n        Charles Sanders Peirce\n       </a>\n       and then\n       <a href="/wiki/William_James" title="William James">\n        William James\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/John_Dewey" title="John Dewey">\n        John Dewey\n       </a>\n       were leaders in the development of\n       <a href="/wiki/Pragmatism" title="Pragmatism">\n        pragmatism\n       </a>\n       . In the 20th century, the work of\n       <a href="/wiki/Willard_Van_Orman_Quine" title="Willard Van Orman Quine">\n        W. V. O. Quine\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Richard_Rorty" title="Richard Rorty">\n        Richard Rorty\n       </a>\n       , and later\n       <a href="/wiki/Noam_Chomsky" title="Noam Chomsky">\n        Noam Chomsky\n       </a>\n       , brought\n       <a href="/wiki/Analytic_philosophy" title="Analytic philosophy">\n        analytic philosophy\n       </a>\n       to the fore of American philosophical academia.\n       <a href="/wiki/John_Rawls" title="John Rawls">\n        John Rawls\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Robert_Nozick" title="Robert Nozick">\n        Robert Nozick\n       </a>\n       led a revival of\n       <a href="/wiki/Political_philosophy" title="Political philosophy">\n        political philosophy\n       </a>\n       .\n       <a href="/wiki/Cornel_West" title="Cornel West">\n        Cornel West\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Judith_Butler" title="Judith Butler">\n        Judith Butler\n       </a>\n       have led a continental tradition in American philosophical academia.\n       <a href="/wiki/Chicago_school_of_economics" title="Chicago school of economics">\n        Chicago school economists\n       </a>\n       like\n       <a href="/wiki/Milton_Friedman" title="Milton Friedman">\n        Milton Friedman\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/James_M._Buchanan" title="James M. Buchanan">\n        James M. Buchanan\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Sowell" title="Thomas Sowell">\n        Thomas Sowell\n       </a>\n       have affected various fields in social and political philosophy.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-623">\n        <a href="#cite_note-623">\n         [607]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-624">\n        <a href="#cite_note-624">\n         [608]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In the visual arts, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River_School" title="Hudson River School">\n        Hudson River School\n       </a>\n       was a mid-19th-century movement in the tradition of European\n       <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">\n        naturalism\n       </a>\n       . The realist paintings of\n       <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Eakins" title="Thomas Eakins">\n        Thomas Eakins\n       </a>\n       are now widely celebrated. The 1913\n       <a href="/wiki/Armory_Show" title="Armory Show">\n        Armory Show\n       </a>\n       in New York City, an exhibition of European\n       <a href="/wiki/Modern_art" title="Modern art">\n        modernist art\n       </a>\n       , shocked the public and transformed the U.S. art scene.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-625">\n        <a href="#cite_note-625">\n         [609]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/Georgia_O%27Keeffe" title="Georgia O\'Keeffe">\n        Georgia O\'Keeffe\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Marsden_Hartley" title="Marsden Hartley">\n        Marsden Hartley\n       </a>\n       , and others experimented with new, individualistic styles. Major artistic movements such as the\n       <a href="/wiki/Abstract_expressionism" title="Abstract expressionism">\n        abstract expressionism\n       </a>\n       of\n       <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Pollock" title="Jackson Pollock">\n        Jackson Pollock\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Willem_de_Kooning" title="Willem de Kooning">\n        Willem de Kooning\n       </a>\n       and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Pop_art" title="Pop art">\n        pop art\n       </a>\n       of\n       <a href="/wiki/Andy_Warhol" title="Andy Warhol">\n        Andy Warhol\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Roy_Lichtenstein" title="Roy Lichtenstein">\n        Roy Lichtenstein\n       </a>\n       developed largely in the United States. The tide of modernism and then\n       <a href="/wiki/Postmodernism" title="Postmodernism">\n        postmodernism\n       </a>\n       has brought fame to American architects such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Frank_Lloyd_Wright" title="Frank Lloyd Wright">\n        Frank Lloyd Wright\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Philip_Johnson" title="Philip Johnson">\n        Philip Johnson\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Frank_Gehry" title="Frank Gehry">\n        Frank Gehry\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JansonJanson2003_626-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-JansonJanson2003-626">\n         [610]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Americans have long been important in the modern artistic medium of\n       <a href="/wiki/Photography" title="Photography">\n        photography\n       </a>\n       , with major photographers including\n       <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Stieglitz" title="Alfred Stieglitz">\n        Alfred Stieglitz\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Edward_Steichen" title="Edward Steichen">\n        Edward Steichen\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Ansel_Adams" title="Ansel Adams">\n        Ansel Adams\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Davenport1991_627-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Davenport1991-627">\n         [611]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Times_Square_1-2.JPG">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Times_Square_1-2.JPG/220px-Times_Square_1-2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Times_Square_1-2.JPG/330px-Times_Square_1-2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Times_Square_1-2.JPG/440px-Times_Square_1-2.JPG 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Times_Square_1-2.JPG" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">\n          Times Square\n         </a>\n         in\n         <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">\n          New York City\n         </a>\n         , the hub of the\n         <a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">\n          Broadway theater\n         </a>\n         <a href="/wiki/Theater_District,_Manhattan" title="Theater District, Manhattan">\n          district\n         </a>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bloom2004_628-0">\n          <a href="#cite_note-Bloom2004-628">\n           [612]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       One of the first major promoters of\n       <a href="/wiki/Theater_of_the_United_States" title="Theater of the United States">\n        American theater\n       </a>\n       was impresario\n       <a href="/wiki/P._T._Barnum" title="P. T. Barnum">\n        P. T. Barnum\n       </a>\n       , who began operating a lower\n       <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">\n        Manhattan\n       </a>\n       entertainment complex in 1841. The team of\n       <a href="/wiki/Edward_Harrigan" title="Edward Harrigan">\n        Harrigan and Hart\n       </a>\n       produced a series of popular\n       <a href="/wiki/Musical_theatre" title="Musical theatre">\n        musical\n       </a>\n       comedies in New York starting in the late 1870s. In the 20th century, the modern musical form emerged on\n       <a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">\n        Broadway\n       </a>\n       ; the songs of musical theater composers such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Irving_Berlin" title="Irving Berlin">\n        Irving Berlin\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Cole_Porter" title="Cole Porter">\n        Cole Porter\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Sondheim" title="Stephen Sondheim">\n        Stephen Sondheim\n       </a>\n       have become\n       <a href="/wiki/Traditional_pop_music" title="Traditional pop music">\n        pop standards\n       </a>\n       . Playwright\n       <a href="/wiki/Eugene_O%27Neill" title="Eugene O\'Neill">\n        Eugene O\'Neill\n       </a>\n       won the Nobel literature prize in 1936; other acclaimed U.S. dramatists include multiple\n       <a href="/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize_for_Drama" title="Pulitzer Prize for Drama">\n        Pulitzer Prize\n       </a>\n       winners\n       <a href="/wiki/Tennessee_Williams" title="Tennessee Williams">\n        Tennessee Williams\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Edward_Albee" title="Edward Albee">\n        Edward Albee\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/August_Wilson" title="August Wilson">\n        August Wilson\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moran2002_629-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Moran2002-629">\n         [613]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Though little known at the time,\n       <a href="/wiki/Charles_Ives" title="Charles Ives">\n        Charles Ives\n       </a>\n       \'s work of the 1910s established him as the first major U.S. composer in the classical tradition, while experimentalists such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Henry_Cowell" title="Henry Cowell">\n        Henry Cowell\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/John_Cage" title="John Cage">\n        John Cage\n       </a>\n       created a distinctive American approach to classical composition.\n       <a href="/wiki/Aaron_Copland" title="Aaron Copland">\n        Aaron Copland\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/George_Gershwin" title="George Gershwin">\n        George Gershwin\n       </a>\n       developed a new synthesis of popular and classical music.\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Choreography" title="Choreography">\n        Choreographers\n       </a>\n       <a href="/wiki/Isadora_Duncan" title="Isadora Duncan">\n        Isadora Duncan\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Martha_Graham" title="Martha Graham">\n        Martha Graham\n       </a>\n       helped create\n       <a href="/wiki/Modern_dance" title="Modern dance">\n        modern dance\n       </a>\n       , while\n       <a href="/wiki/George_Balanchine" title="George Balanchine">\n        George Balanchine\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Jerome_Robbins" title="Jerome Robbins">\n        Jerome Robbins\n       </a>\n       were leaders in 20th-century ballet.\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Music">\n        Music\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States" title="Music of the United States">\n        Music of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="837" data-file-width="1199" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg/220px-Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg/330px-Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg/440px-Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indeterminate_Grammy_aware.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The\n         <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">\n          Grammy Award\n         </a>\n         is awarded to leading music artists.\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The rhythmic and lyrical styles of\n       <a href="/wiki/African-American_music" title="African-American music">\n        African-American music\n       </a>\n       have deeply influenced\n       <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_States" title="Music of the United States">\n        American music\n       </a>\n       at large, distinguishing it from European traditions. Elements from\n       <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">\n        folk\n       </a>\n       idioms such as the\n       <a href="/wiki/Blues" title="Blues">\n        blues\n       </a>\n       and what is now known as\n       <a href="/wiki/Old-time_music" title="Old-time music">\n        old-time music\n       </a>\n       were adopted and transformed into\n       <a href="/wiki/Popular_music" title="Popular music">\n        popular genres\n       </a>\n       with global audiences.\n       <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">\n        Jazz\n       </a>\n       was developed by innovators such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Louis_Armstrong" title="Louis Armstrong">\n        Louis Armstrong\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Duke_Ellington" title="Duke Ellington">\n        Duke Ellington\n       </a>\n       early in the 20th century.\n       <a href="/wiki/Country_music" title="Country music">\n        Country music\n       </a>\n       developed in the 1920s, and\n       <a href="/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues" title="Rhythm and blues">\n        rhythm and blues\n       </a>\n       in the 1940s.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2001_630-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2001-630">\n         [614]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">\n        Elvis Presley\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Berry" title="Chuck Berry">\n        Chuck Berry\n       </a>\n       were among the mid-1950s pioneers of\n       <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_roll" title="Rock and roll">\n        rock and roll\n       </a>\n       . In the 1960s,\n       <a href="/wiki/Bob_Dylan" title="Bob Dylan">\n        Bob Dylan\n       </a>\n       emerged from the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_folk_music_revival" title="American folk music revival">\n        folk revival\n       </a>\n       to become one of America\'s most celebrated songwriters and\n       <a href="/wiki/James_Brown" title="James Brown">\n        James Brown\n       </a>\n       led the development of\n       <a href="/wiki/Funk" title="Funk">\n        funk\n       </a>\n       . More recent American creations include\n       <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">\n        hip hop\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/House_music" title="House music">\n        house music\n       </a>\n       . American pop stars such as Presley,\n       <a href="/wiki/Michael_Jackson" title="Michael Jackson">\n        Michael Jackson\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Madonna_(entertainer)" title="Madonna (entertainer)">\n        Madonna\n       </a>\n       have become global celebrities,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated2001_630-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2001-630">\n         [614]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       as have contemporary musical artists such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Taylor_Swift" title="Taylor Swift">\n        Taylor Swift\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Britney_Spears" title="Britney Spears">\n        Britney Spears\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Katy_Perry" title="Katy Perry">\n        Katy Perry\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyonc\xc3\xa9">\n        Beyonc\xc3\xa9\n       </a>\n       as well as hip hop artists\n       <a href="/wiki/Jay-Z" title="Jay-Z">\n        Jay-Z\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Eminem" title="Eminem">\n        Eminem\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">\n        Kanye West\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-631">\n        <a href="#cite_note-631">\n         [615]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Rock bands such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Metallica" title="Metallica">\n        Metallica\n       </a>\n       , the\n       <a href="/wiki/Eagles_(band)" title="Eagles (band)">\n        Eagles\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Aerosmith" title="Aerosmith">\n        Aerosmith\n       </a>\n       are among the\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">\n        highest grossing\n       </a>\n       in worldwide sales.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-632">\n        <a href="#cite_note-632">\n         [616]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-633">\n        <a href="#cite_note-633">\n         [617]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-634">\n        <a href="#cite_note-634">\n         [618]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">\n        Cinema\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States" title="Cinema of the United States">\n        Cinema of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HollywoodSign.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3456" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/HollywoodSign.jpg/220px-HollywoodSign.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/HollywoodSign.jpg/330px-HollywoodSign.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/HollywoodSign.jpg/440px-HollywoodSign.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HollywoodSign.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The\n         <a href="/wiki/Hollywood_Sign" title="Hollywood Sign">\n          Hollywood Sign\n         </a>\n         in\n         <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">\n          Los Angeles\n         </a>\n         , California\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/Hollywood" title="Hollywood">\n        Hollywood\n       </a>\n       , a northern district of\n       <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">\n        Los Angeles\n       </a>\n       , California, is one of the leaders in motion picture production.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-635">\n        <a href="#cite_note-635">\n         [619]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The world\'s first commercial motion picture exhibition was given in New York City in 1894, using\n       <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Edison" title="Thomas Edison">\n        Thomas Edison\n       </a>\n       \'s\n       <a href="/wiki/Kinetoscope" title="Kinetoscope">\n        Kinetoscope\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-636">\n        <a href="#cite_note-636">\n         [620]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The next year saw the first commercial screening of a projected film, also in New York, and the United States was in the forefront of\n       <a href="/wiki/Sound_film" title="Sound film">\n        sound film\n       </a>\n       \'s development in the following decades. Since the early 20th century, the U.S. film industry has largely been based in and around Hollywood, although in the 21st century an increasing number of films are not made there, and film companies have been subject to the forces of globalization.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-637">\n        <a href="#cite_note-637">\n         [621]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Director\n       <a href="/wiki/D._W._Griffith" title="D. W. Griffith">\n        D. W. Griffith\n       </a>\n       , the top American\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filmmaker" title="Filmmaker">\n        filmmaker\n       </a>\n       during the silent film period, was central to the development of\n       <a href="/wiki/Film_grammar" title="Film grammar">\n        film grammar\n       </a>\n       , and producer/entrepreneur\n       <a href="/wiki/Walt_Disney" title="Walt Disney">\n        Walt Disney\n       </a>\n       was a leader in both\n       <a href="/wiki/Animation" title="Animation">\n        animated film\n       </a>\n       and movie\n       <a href="/wiki/Merchandising" title="Merchandising">\n        merchandising\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KrasniewiczDisney2010_638-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-KrasniewiczDisney2010-638">\n         [622]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Directors such as\n       <a href="/wiki/John_Ford" title="John Ford">\n        John Ford\n       </a>\n       redefined the image of the American Old West and history, and, like others such as\n       <a href="/wiki/John_Huston" title="John Huston">\n        John Huston\n       </a>\n       , broadened the possibilities of cinema with location shooting, with great influence on subsequent directors. The industry enjoyed its golden years, in what is commonly referred to as the "\n       <a href="/wiki/Classical_Hollywood_cinema" title="Classical Hollywood cinema">\n        Golden Age of Hollywood\n       </a>\n       ", from the early sound period until the early 1960s,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-639">\n        <a href="#cite_note-639">\n         [623]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       with screen actors such as\n       <a href="/wiki/John_Wayne" title="John Wayne">\n        John Wayne\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Marilyn_Monroe" title="Marilyn Monroe">\n        Marilyn Monroe\n       </a>\n       becoming iconic figures.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-640">\n        <a href="#cite_note-640">\n         [624]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-641">\n        <a href="#cite_note-641">\n         [625]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In the 1970s, film directors such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Martin_Scorsese" title="Martin Scorsese">\n        Martin Scorsese\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Francis_Ford_Coppola" title="Francis Ford Coppola">\n        Francis Ford Coppola\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Robert_Altman" title="Robert Altman">\n        Robert Altman\n       </a>\n       were a vital component in what became known as "\n       <a href="/wiki/New_Hollywood" title="New Hollywood">\n        New Hollywood\n       </a>\n       " or the "Hollywood Renaissance",\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Greven2013_642-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Greven2013-642">\n         [626]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       grittier films influenced by French and Italian realist pictures of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Aftermath_of_World_War_II" title="Aftermath of World War II">\n        post-war period\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morrison1998_643-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Morrison1998-643">\n         [627]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Since, directors such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Steven_Spielberg" title="Steven Spielberg">\n        Steven Spielberg\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/George_Lucas" title="George Lucas">\n        George Lucas\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/James_Cameron" title="James Cameron">\n        James Cameron\n       </a>\n       have gained renown for their blockbuster films, often characterized by high production costs, and in return, high earnings at the box office, with Cameron\'s\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Avatar_(2009_film)" title="Avatar (2009 film)">\n         Avatar\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (2009) earning more than $2 billion.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Turow2011_644-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Turow2011-644">\n         [628]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Notable films topping the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Film_Institute" title="American Film Institute">\n        American Film Institute\n       </a>\n       \'s\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AFI_100" title="AFI 100">\n        AFI 100\n       </a>\n       list include\n       <a href="/wiki/Orson_Welles" title="Orson Welles">\n        Orson Welles\n       </a>\n       \'s\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Citizen_Kane" title="Citizen Kane">\n         Citizen Kane\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1941), which is frequently cited as the greatest film of all time,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-645">\n        <a href="#cite_note-645">\n         [629]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-646">\n        <a href="#cite_note-646">\n         [630]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Casablanca_(film)" title="Casablanca (film)">\n         Casablanca\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1942),\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/The_Godfather" title="The Godfather">\n         The Godfather\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1972),\n       <i>\n        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gone_with_the_Wind_(1939_film)" title="Gone with the Wind (1939 film)">\n         Gone with the Wind\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1939),\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Lawrence_of_Arabia_(film)" title="Lawrence of Arabia (film)">\n         Lawrence of Arabia\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1962),\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/The_Wizard_of_Oz_(1939_film)" title="The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)">\n         The Wizard of Oz\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1939),\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/The_Graduate" title="The Graduate">\n         The Graduate\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1967),\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/On_the_Waterfront" title="On the Waterfront">\n         On the Waterfront\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1954),\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Schindler%27s_List" title="Schindler\'s List">\n         Schindler\'s List\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1993),\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Singin%27_in_the_Rain" title="Singin\' in the Rain">\n         Singin\' in the Rain\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1952),\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/It%27s_a_Wonderful_Life" title="It\'s a Wonderful Life">\n         It\'s a Wonderful Life\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1946) and\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/Sunset_Boulevard_(film)" title="Sunset Boulevard (film)">\n         Sunset Boulevard\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       (1950).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-647">\n        <a href="#cite_note-647">\n         [631]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The\n       <a href="/wiki/Academy_Awards" title="Academy Awards">\n        Academy Awards\n       </a>\n       , popularly known as the Oscars, have been held annually by the\n       <a href="/wiki/Academy_of_Motion_Picture_Arts_and_Sciences" title="Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences">\n        Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences\n       </a>\n       since 1929,\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DrowneHuber2004_648-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-DrowneHuber2004-648">\n         [632]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       and the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Golden_Globe_Awards" title="Golden Globe Awards">\n        Golden Globe Awards\n       </a>\n       have been held annually since January 1944.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kroon2014_649-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Kroon2014-649">\n         [633]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">\n        Sports\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_the_United_States" title="Sports in the United States">\n        Sports in the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:342px;max-width:342px">\n        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:169px;max-width:169px">\n         <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">\n          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arian_Foster_fumble.jpg">\n           <img alt="" data-file-height="1353" data-file-width="2029" height="111" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Arian_Foster_fumble.jpg/167px-Arian_Foster_fumble.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Arian_Foster_fumble.jpg/251px-Arian_Foster_fumble.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Arian_Foster_fumble.jpg/334px-Arian_Foster_fumble.jpg 2x" width="167"/>\n          </a>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:169px;max-width:169px">\n         <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">\n          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:David-ortiz-batters-box.JPG">\n           <img alt="" data-file-height="1450" data-file-width="2175" height="111" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/David-ortiz-batters-box.JPG/167px-David-ortiz-batters-box.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/David-ortiz-batters-box.JPG/251px-David-ortiz-batters-box.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/David-ortiz-batters-box.JPG/334px-David-ortiz-batters-box.JPG 2x" width="167"/>\n          </a>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n        <div style="clear:left">\n        </div>\n        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:169px;max-width:169px">\n         <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">\n          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Trevor_Booker_Troy_Murphy.jpg">\n           <img alt="" data-file-height="1908" data-file-width="2247" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Trevor_Booker_Troy_Murphy.jpg/167px-Trevor_Booker_Troy_Murphy.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Trevor_Booker_Troy_Murphy.jpg/251px-Trevor_Booker_Troy_Murphy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Trevor_Booker_Troy_Murphy.jpg/334px-Trevor_Booker_Troy_Murphy.jpg 2x" width="167"/>\n          </a>\n         </div>\n        </div>\n        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:169px;max-width:169px">\n         <div class="thumbimage" style="height:111px;overflow:hidden">\n          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:151005-F-ZJ145-361_(22030960390).jpg">\n           <img alt="" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="3600" height="111" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/151005-F-ZJ145-361_%2822030960390%29.jpg/167px-151005-F-ZJ145-361_%2822030960390%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/151005-F-ZJ145-361_%2822030960390%29.jpg/251px-151005-F-ZJ145-361_%2822030960390%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/151005-F-ZJ145-361_%2822030960390%29.jpg/334px-151005-F-ZJ145-361_%2822030960390%29.jpg 2x" width="167"/>\n          </a>\n         </div>\n
