</div>\n        <div style="clear:left">\n        </div>\n        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">\n         Most popular American sports are\n         <a href="/wiki/American_football" title="American football">\n          American football\n         </a>\n         ,\n         <a href="/wiki/Baseball" title="Baseball">\n          baseball\n         </a>\n         ,\n         <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">\n          basketball\n         </a>\n         and\n         <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">\n          ice hockey\n         </a>\n         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-650">\n          <a href="#cite_note-650">\n           [634]\n          </a>\n         </sup>\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       <a href="/wiki/American_football" title="American football">\n        American football\n       </a>\n       is by several measures the most popular spectator sport;\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-651">\n        <a href="#cite_note-651">\n         [635]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       the\n       <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">\n        National Football League\n       </a>\n       (NFL) has the highest average attendance of any sports league in the world, and the\n       <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl" title="Super Bowl">\n        Super Bowl\n       </a>\n       is watched by millions globally.\n       <a href="/wiki/Baseball" title="Baseball">\n        Baseball\n       </a>\n       has been regarded as the U.S.\n       <a href="/wiki/National_sport" title="National sport">\n        national sport\n       </a>\n       since the late 19th century, with\n       <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">\n        Major League Baseball\n       </a>\n       (MLB) being the top league.\n       <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">\n        Basketball\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">\n        ice hockey\n       </a>\n       are the country\'s next two\n       <a href="/wiki/Major_professional_sports_leagues_in_the_United_States_and_Canada" title="Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada">\n        leading professional team sports\n       </a>\n       , with the top leagues being the\n       <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">\n        National Basketball Association\n       </a>\n       (NBA) and the\n       <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">\n        National Hockey League\n       </a>\n       (NHL). These four major sports, when played professionally, each occupy a season at different, but overlapping, times of the year.\n       <a href="/wiki/College_football" title="College football">\n        College football\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/College_basketball" title="College basketball">\n        basketball\n       </a>\n       attract large audiences.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-652">\n        <a href="#cite_note-652">\n         [636]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In\n       <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">\n        soccer\n       </a>\n       , the country hosted the\n       <a href="/wiki/1994_FIFA_World_Cup" title="1994 FIFA World Cup">\n        1994 FIFA World Cup\n       </a>\n       , the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team" title="United States men\'s national soccer team">\n        men\'s national soccer team\n       </a>\n       qualified for ten World Cups and the\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_women%27s_national_soccer_team" title="United States women\'s national soccer team">\n        women\'s team\n       </a>\n       has won the\n       <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Women%27s_World_Cup" title="FIFA Women\'s World Cup">\n        FIFA Women\'s World Cup\n       </a>\n       three times;\n       <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Soccer" title="Major League Soccer">\n        Major League Soccer\n       </a>\n       is the sport\'s highest league in the United States (featuring 19 American and 3 Canadian teams). The market for professional sports in the United States is roughly $69 billion, roughly 50% larger than that of all of Europe, the Middle East, and Africa combined.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-653">\n        <a href="#cite_note-653">\n         [637]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Eight\n       <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">\n        Olympic Games\n       </a>\n       have taken place in the United States. As of 2014, the United States has won 2,400 medals at the\n       <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">\n        Summer Olympic Games\n       </a>\n       , more than any other country, and 281 in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">\n        Winter Olympic Games\n       </a>\n       , the second most behind Norway.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-654">\n        <a href="#cite_note-654">\n         [638]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       While most major U.S. sports have evolved out of European practices,\n       <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">\n        basketball\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">\n        volleyball\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Skateboarding" title="Skateboarding">\n        skateboarding\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Snowboarding" title="Snowboarding">\n        snowboarding\n       </a>\n       are American inventions, some of which have become popular in other countries.\n       <a href="/wiki/Lacrosse" title="Lacrosse">\n        Lacrosse\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Surfing" title="Surfing">\n        surfing\n       </a>\n       arose from Native American and Native Hawaiian activities that predate Western contact.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-liss_655-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-liss-655">\n         [639]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The most watched\n       <a href="/wiki/Individual_sport" title="Individual sport">\n        individual sports\n       </a>\n       are\n       <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">\n        golf\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Auto_racing" title="Auto racing">\n        auto racing\n       </a>\n       , particularly\n       <a href="/wiki/NASCAR" title="NASCAR">\n        NASCAR\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-656">\n        <a href="#cite_note-656">\n         [640]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-657">\n        <a href="#cite_note-657">\n         [641]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">\n        Rugby union\n       </a>\n       is considered the fastest growing sport in the U.S., with registered players numbered at 115,000+ and a further 1.2 million participants.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-658">\n        <a href="#cite_note-658">\n         [642]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h3>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">\n        Media\n       </span>\n      </h3>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main article:\n       <a href="/wiki/Media_of_the_United_States" title="Media of the United States">\n        Media of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2224" data-file-width="2845" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG/220px-ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG/330px-ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG/440px-ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ABC_77_W66_jeh.JPG" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         The corporate headquarters of the\n         <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">\n          American Broadcasting Company\n         </a>\n         in New York City\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The four major broadcasters in the U.S. are the\n       <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">\n        National Broadcasting Company\n       </a>\n       (NBC),\n       <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">\n        Columbia Broadcasting System\n       </a>\n       (CBS), the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">\n        American Broadcasting Company\n       </a>\n       (ABC), and\n       <a href="/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">\n        Fox\n       </a>\n       . The four major broadcast\n       <a href="/wiki/Television_network" title="Television network">\n        television networks\n       </a>\n       are all commercial entities.\n       <a href="/wiki/Cable_television_in_the_United_States" title="Cable television in the United States">\n        Cable television\n       </a>\n       offers hundreds of channels catering to a variety of niches.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-659">\n        <a href="#cite_note-659">\n         [643]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Americans listen to radio programming, also largely commercial, on average just over two-and-a-half hours a day.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-660">\n        <a href="#cite_note-660">\n         [644]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In 1998, the number of U.S. commercial radio stations had grown to 4,793 AM stations and 5,662 FM stations. In addition, there are 1,460 public radio stations. Most of these stations are run by universities and public authorities for educational purposes and are financed by public or private funds, subscriptions and corporate underwriting. Much public-radio broadcasting is supplied by\n       <a href="/wiki/NPR" title="NPR">\n        NPR\n       </a>\n       (formerly National Public Radio). NPR was incorporated in February 1970 under the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967; its television counterpart,\n       <a href="/wiki/PBS" title="PBS">\n        PBS\n       </a>\n       , was also created by the same legislation. (NPR and PBS are operated separately from each other.) As of September 30, 2014\n       <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">\n        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit">\n         [update]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       , there are 15,433 licensed full-power radio stations in the U.S. according to the\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Federal_Communications_Commission" title="U.S. Federal Communications Commission">\n        U.S. Federal Communications Commission\n       </a>\n       (FCC).\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-661">\n        <a href="#cite_note-661">\n         [645]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Well-known newspapers include\n       <i>\n        The\n        <a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">\n         Wall Street Journal\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       ,\n       <i>\n        The\n        <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">\n         New York Times\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       and\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/USA_Today" title="USA Today">\n         USA Today\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Shaffer2006_662-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Shaffer2006-662">\n         [646]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Although the cost of publishing has increased over the years, the price of newspapers has generally remained low, forcing newspapers to rely more on advertising revenue and on articles provided by a major wire service, such as the Associated Press or Reuters, for their national and world coverage. With very few exceptions, all the newspapers in the U.S. are privately owned, either by large chains such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Gannett_Company" title="Gannett Company">\n        Gannett\n       </a>\n       or\n       <a href="/wiki/The_McClatchy_Company" title="The McClatchy Company">\n        McClatchy\n       </a>\n       , which own dozens or even hundreds of newspapers; by small chains that own a handful of papers; or in a situation that is increasingly rare, by individuals or families. Major cities often have "alternative weeklies" to complement the mainstream daily papers, for example, New York City\'s\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/The_Village_Voice" title="The Village Voice">\n         The Village Voice\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       or Los Angeles\'\n       <i>\n        <a href="/wiki/LA_Weekly" title="LA Weekly">\n         LA Weekly\n        </a>\n       </i>\n       , to name two of the best-known. Major cities may also support a local business journal, trade papers relating to local industries, and papers for local ethnic and social groups. Early versions of the American newspaper\n       <a href="/wiki/Comic_strip" title="Comic strip">\n        comic strip\n       </a>\n       and the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_comic_book" title="American comic book">\n        American comic book\n       </a>\n       began appearing in the 19th century. In 1938,\n       <a href="/wiki/Superman" title="Superman">\n        Superman\n       </a>\n       , the comic book\n       <a href="/wiki/Superhero" title="Superhero">\n        superhero\n       </a>\n       of\n       <a href="/wiki/DC_Comics" title="DC Comics">\n        DC Comics\n       </a>\n       , developed into an American icon.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-663">\n        <a href="#cite_note-663">\n         [647]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Aside from\n       <a href="/wiki/Web_portal" title="Web portal">\n        web portals\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Web_search_engine" title="Web search engine">\n        search engines\n       </a>\n       , the most popular websites are\n       <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">\n        Facebook\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/YouTube" title="YouTube">\n        YouTube\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia" title="Wikipedia">\n        Wikipedia\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Yahoo!" title="Yahoo!">\n        Yahoo!\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/EBay" title="EBay">\n        eBay\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amazon.com" title="Amazon.com">\n        Amazon\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">\n        Twitter\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alexa-topsitesus_664-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-alexa-topsitesus-664">\n         [648]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       More than 800 publications are produced in Spanish, the second most commonly used language in the United States behind English.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-665">\n        <a href="#cite_note-665">\n         [649]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-666">\n        <a href="#cite_note-666">\n         [650]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">\n        Science and technology\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       Main articles:\n       <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_United_States" title="Science and technology in the United States">\n        Science and technology in the United States\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Science_policy_of_the_United_States" title="Science policy of the United States">\n        Science policy of the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Apollo_15_flag,_rover,_LM,_Irwin_cropped.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1642" data-file-width="2394" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Apollo_15_flag%2C_rover%2C_LM%2C_Irwin_cropped.jpg/220px-Apollo_15_flag%2C_rover%2C_LM%2C_Irwin_cropped.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Apollo_15_flag%2C_rover%2C_LM%2C_Irwin_cropped.jpg/330px-Apollo_15_flag%2C_rover%2C_LM%2C_Irwin_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Apollo_15_flag%2C_rover%2C_LM%2C_Irwin_cropped.jpg/440px-Apollo_15_flag%2C_rover%2C_LM%2C_Irwin_cropped.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Apollo_15_flag,_rover,_LM,_Irwin_cropped.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         Astronaut\n         <a href="/wiki/James_Irwin" title="James Irwin">\n          James Irwin\n         </a>\n         walking on the\n         <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">\n          Moon\n         </a>\n         next to\n         <a href="/wiki/Apollo_15" title="Apollo 15">\n          Apollo 15\n         </a>\n         \'s\n         <a href="/wiki/Apollo_Lunar_Module" title="Apollo Lunar Module">\n          landing module\n         </a>\n         and\n         <a href="/wiki/Lunar_rover" title="Lunar rover">\n          lunar rover\n         </a>\n         in 1971. The effort to reach the Moon was triggered by the\n         <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">\n          Space Race\n         </a>\n         .\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The United States has been a leader in technological innovation since the late 19th century and scientific research since the mid-20th century. Methods for producing\n       <a href="/wiki/Interchangeable_parts" title="Interchangeable parts">\n        interchangeable parts\n       </a>\n       were developed by the U.S. War Department by the Federal Armories during the first half of the 19th century. This technology, along with the establishment of a\n       <a href="/wiki/Machine_tool" title="Machine tool">\n        machine tool\n       </a>\n       industry, enabled the U.S. to have large scale manufacturing of sewing machines, bicycles and other items in the late 19th century and became known as the\n       <a href="/wiki/American_system_of_manufacturing" title="American system of manufacturing">\n        American system of manufacturing\n       </a>\n       . Factory\n       <a href="/wiki/Electrification" title="Electrification">\n        electrification\n       </a>\n       in the early 20th century and introduction of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Assembly_line" title="Assembly line">\n        assembly line\n       </a>\n       and other labor saving techniques created the system called\n       <a href="/wiki/Mass_production" title="Mass production">\n        mass production\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-667">\n        <a href="#cite_note-667">\n         [651]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In 1876,\n       <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Graham_Bell" title="Alexander Graham Bell">\n        Alexander Graham Bell\n       </a>\n       was awarded the first U.S.\n       <a href="/wiki/Invention_of_the_telephone" title="Invention of the telephone">\n        patent for the telephone\n       </a>\n       .\n       <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Edison" title="Thomas Edison">\n        Thomas Edison\n       </a>\n       \'s\n       <a href="/wiki/Research_institute" title="Research institute">\n        research laboratory\n       </a>\n       , one of the first of its kind, developed the\n       <a href="/wiki/Phonograph" title="Phonograph">\n        phonograph\n       </a>\n       , the first\n       <a href="/wiki/Incandescent_light_bulb" title="Incandescent light bulb">\n        long-lasting light bulb\n       </a>\n       , and the first viable\n       <a href="/wiki/Kinetoscope" title="Kinetoscope">\n        movie camera\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edison_668-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Edison-668">\n         [652]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The latter lead to emergence of the worldwide\n       <a href="/wiki/Show_business" title="Show business">\n        entertainment industry\n       </a>\n       . In the early 20th century, the automobile companies of\n       <a href="/wiki/Ransom_E._Olds" title="Ransom E. Olds">\n        Ransom E. Olds\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Henry_Ford" title="Henry Ford">\n        Henry Ford\n       </a>\n       popularized the\n       <a href="/wiki/Assembly_line" title="Assembly line">\n        assembly line\n       </a>\n       . The\n       <a href="/wiki/Wright_brothers" title="Wright brothers">\n        Wright brothers\n       </a>\n       , in 1903, made the\n       <a href="/wiki/Wright_Flyer" title="Wright Flyer">\n        first sustained and controlled heavier-than-air powered flight\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-669">\n        <a href="#cite_note-669">\n         [653]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The rise of\n       <a href="/wiki/Fascism" title="Fascism">\n        Fascism\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Nazism" title="Nazism">\n        Nazism\n       </a>\n       in the 1920s and 1930s led many European scientists, including\n       <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">\n        Albert Einstein\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Enrico_Fermi" title="Enrico Fermi">\n        Enrico Fermi\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">\n        John von Neumann\n       </a>\n       , to immigrate to the United States.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fraser_670-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-fraser-670">\n         [654]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       During World War II, the\n       <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Project" title="Manhattan Project">\n        Manhattan Project\n       </a>\n       developed nuclear weapons, ushering in the\n       <a href="/wiki/Atomic_Age" title="Atomic Age">\n        Atomic Age\n       </a>\n       , while the\n       <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">\n        Space Race\n       </a>\n       produced rapid advances in rocketry,\n       <a href="/wiki/Materials_science" title="Materials science">\n        materials science\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Aeronautics" title="Aeronautics">\n        aeronautics\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-671">\n        <a href="#cite_note-671">\n         [655]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-672">\n        <a href="#cite_note-672">\n         [656]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The invention of the\n       <a href="/wiki/Transistor" title="Transistor">\n        transistor\n       </a>\n       in the 1950s, a key active component in practically all modern\n       <a href="/wiki/Electronics" title="Electronics">\n        electronics\n       </a>\n       , led to many technological developments and a significant expansion of the U.S. technology industry.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-673">\n        <a href="#cite_note-673">\n         [657]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-674">\n        <a href="#cite_note-674">\n         [658]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-675">\n        <a href="#cite_note-675">\n         [659]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       This in turn led to the establishment of many new technology companies and regions around the country such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">\n        Silicon Valley\n       </a>\n       in California. Advancements by American\n       <a href="/wiki/Microprocessor" title="Microprocessor">\n        microprocessor\n       </a>\n       companies such as\n       <a href="/wiki/Advanced_Micro_Devices" title="Advanced Micro Devices">\n        Advanced Micro Devices\n       </a>\n       (AMD), and\n       <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">\n        Intel\n       </a>\n       along with both computer\n       <a href="/wiki/Software" title="Software">\n        software\n       </a>\n       and\n       <a href="/wiki/Computer_hardware" title="Computer hardware">\n        hardware\n       </a>\n       companies that include\n       <a href="/wiki/Adobe_Systems" title="Adobe Systems">\n        Adobe Systems\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Apple_Inc." title="Apple Inc.">\n        Apple Inc.\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">\n        IBM\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Microsoft" title="Microsoft">\n        Microsoft\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Sun_Microsystems" title="Sun Microsystems">\n        Sun Microsystems\n       </a>\n       created and popularized the\n       <a href="/wiki/Personal_computer" title="Personal computer">\n        personal computer\n       </a>\n       . The\n       <a href="/wiki/ARPANET" title="ARPANET">\n        ARPANET\n       </a>\n       was developed in the 1960s to meet\n       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Defense" title="United States Department of Defense">\n        Defense Department\n       </a>\n       requirements, and became the first of a\n       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Internet" title="History of the Internet">\n        series of networks which evolved\n       </a>\n       into the\n       <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">\n        Internet\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sawyer2012_676-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Sawyer2012-676">\n         [660]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       These advancements then lead to greater\n       <a href="/wiki/Personalization" title="Personalization">\n        personalization\n       </a>\n       of technology for individual use.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-677">\n        <a href="#cite_note-677">\n         [661]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       As of 2013\n       <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">\n        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit">\n         [update]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       , 83.8% of American households owned at least one\n       <a href="/wiki/Computer" title="Computer">\n        computer\n       </a>\n       , and 73.3% had high-speed Internet service.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-678">\n        <a href="#cite_note-678">\n         [662]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       91% of Americans also own a mobile phone as of May 2013\n       <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">\n        <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit">\n         [update]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-679">\n        <a href="#cite_note-679">\n         [663]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The United States ranks highly with regard to freedom of use of the internet.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-680">\n        <a href="#cite_note-680">\n         [664]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In the 21st century, approximately two-thirds of research and development funding comes from the private sector.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-681">\n        <a href="#cite_note-681">\n         [665]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The United States leads the world in scientific research papers and\n       <a href="/wiki/Impact_factor" title="Impact factor">\n        impact factor\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-682">\n        <a href="#cite_note-682">\n         [666]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Health">\n        Health\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">\n       See also:\n       <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_the_United_States" title="Health care in the United States">\n        Health care in the United States\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Health_care_reform_in_the_United_States" title="Health care reform in the United States">\n        Health care reform in the United States\n       </a>\n       , and\n       <a href="/wiki/Health_insurance_in_the_United_States" title="Health insurance in the United States">\n        Health insurance in the United States\n       </a>\n      </div>\n      <div class="thumb tright">\n       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">\n        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg">\n         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="587" data-file-width="800" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg/220px-NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg/330px-NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg/440px-NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg 2x" width="220"/>\n        </a>\n        <div class="thumbcaption">\n         <div class="magnify">\n          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg" title="Enlarge">\n          </a>\n         </div>\n         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York-Presbyterian_Hospital" title="New York-Presbyterian Hospital">\n          New York-Presbyterian Hospital\n         </a>\n         in\n         <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">\n          New York City\n         </a>\n         is one of the world\'s busiest\n         <a href="/wiki/Hospital" title="Hospital">\n          hospitals\n         </a>\n         . Pictured is the\n         <a href="/wiki/Weill_Cornell_Graduate_School_of_Medical_Sciences" title="Weill Cornell Graduate School of Medical Sciences">\n          Weill Cornell\n         </a>\n         facility (white complex at center).\n        </div>\n       </div>\n      </div>\n      <p>\n       The United States has a life expectancy of 79.8 years at birth, up from 75.2 years in 1990.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-who_683-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-who-683">\n         [667]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-684">\n        <a href="#cite_note-684">\n         [668]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Murray2013_685-0">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Murray2013-685">\n         [669]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The infant mortality rate of 6.17 per thousand places the United States 56th-lowest out of 224 countries.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-686">\n        <a href="#cite_note-686">\n         [670]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Increasing\n       <a href="/wiki/Obesity_in_the_United_States" title="Obesity in the United States">\n        obesity in the United States\n       </a>\n       and health improvements elsewhere contributed to lowering the country\'s rank in life expectancy from 11th in the world in 1987, to 42nd in 2007.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-687">\n        <a href="#cite_note-687">\n         [671]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Obesity rates have more than doubled in the last 30 years, are the highest in the industrialized world, and are among the highest anywhere.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-688">\n        <a href="#cite_note-688">\n         [672]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-689">\n        <a href="#cite_note-689">\n         [673]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Approximately one-third of the adult population is obese and an additional third is overweight.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-690">\n        <a href="#cite_note-690">\n         [674]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Obesity-related\n       <a href="/wiki/Diabetes_mellitus_type_2" title="Diabetes mellitus type 2">\n        type 2 diabetes\n       </a>\n       is considered epidemic by health care professionals.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-691">\n        <a href="#cite_note-691">\n         [675]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       In 2010,\n       <a href="/wiki/Coronary_artery_disease" title="Coronary artery disease">\n        coronary artery disease\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Lung_cancer" title="Lung cancer">\n        lung cancer\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Stroke" title="Stroke">\n        stroke\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Chronic_obstructive_pulmonary_disease" title="Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease">\n        chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases\n       </a>\n       , and traffic accidents caused the most years of life lost in the U.S. Low back pain,\n       <a href="/wiki/Major_depressive_disorder" title="Major depressive disorder">\n        depression\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Musculoskeletal_disorder" title="Musculoskeletal disorder">\n        musculoskeletal disorders\n       </a>\n       , neck pain, and\n       <a href="/wiki/Anxiety" title="Anxiety">\n        anxiety\n       </a>\n       caused the most years lost to disability. The most deleterious\n       <a href="/wiki/Risk_factor" title="Risk factor">\n        risk factors\n       </a>\n       were poor diet, tobacco smoking, obesity,\n       <a href="/wiki/Hypertension" title="Hypertension">\n        high blood pressure\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a href="/wiki/Hyperglycemia" title="Hyperglycemia">\n        high blood sugar\n       </a>\n       ,\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Physical_inactivity" title="Physical inactivity">\n        physical inactivity\n       </a>\n       , and alcohol use.\n       <a href="/wiki/Alzheimer%27s_disease" title="Alzheimer\'s disease">\n        Alzheimer\'s disease\n       </a>\n       , drug abuse,\n       <a href="/wiki/Kidney_disease" title="Kidney disease">\n        kidney disease\n       </a>\n       , cancer, and falls caused the most additional years of life lost over their age-adjusted 1990 per-capita rates.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Murray2013_685-1">\n        <a href="#cite_note-Murray2013-685">\n         [669]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       U.S. teenage pregnancy and abortion rates are substantially higher than in other Western nations, especially among blacks and Hispanics.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-692">\n        <a href="#cite_note-692">\n         [676]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       The U.S. is a global leader in medical innovation. America solely developed or contributed significantly to 9 of the top 10 most important medical innovations since 1975 as ranked by a 2001 poll of physicians, while the European Union and Switzerland together contributed to five.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-693">\n        <a href="#cite_note-693">\n         [677]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       Since 1966, more Americans have received the\n       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Nobel_laureates_in_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="List of Nobel laureates in Physiology or Medicine">\n        Nobel Prize in Medicine\n       </a>\n       than the rest of the world combined. From 1989 to 2002, four times more money was invested in private biotechnology companies in America than in Europe.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-694">\n        <a href="#cite_note-694">\n         [678]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The U.S. health-care system far\n       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_total_health_expenditure_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by total health expenditure (PPP) per capita">\n        outspends\n       </a>\n       any other nation, measured in both per capita spending and percentage of GDP.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-695">\n        <a href="#cite_note-695">\n         [679]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <p>\n       Health-care coverage in the United States is a combination of public and private efforts and is not\n       <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">\n        universal\n       </a>\n       . In 2014, 13.4% of the population did not carry\n       <a href="/wiki/Health_insurance" title="Health insurance">\n        health insurance\n       </a>\n       .\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-696">\n        <a href="#cite_note-696">\n         [680]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       The subject of uninsured and underinsured Americans is a major political issue.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-697">\n        <a href="#cite_note-697">\n         [681]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-698">\n        <a href="#cite_note-698">\n         [682]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       In 2006,\n       <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts" title="Massachusetts">\n        Massachusetts\n       </a>\n       became the first state to mandate universal health insurance.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-699">\n        <a href="#cite_note-699">\n         [683]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <a href="/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act" title="Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act">\n        Federal legislation\n       </a>\n       passed in early 2010 would ostensibly create a near-universal health insurance system around the country by 2014, though the bill and its ultimate effect are issues of controversy.\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-700">\n        <a href="#cite_note-700">\n         [684]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-701">\n        <a href="#cite_note-701">\n         [685]\n        </a>\n       </sup>\n      </p>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">\n        See also\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright" role="navigation" style="margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em;border:solid #aaa 1px">\n       <ul style="display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold">\n        <li style="display:table-row">\n         <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center">\n          <img alt="flag" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="650" data-file-width="1235" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/32px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/48px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/64px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="32"/>\n         </span>\n         <span style="display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle">\n          <a href="/wiki/Portal:United_States" title="Portal:United States">\n           United States portal\n          </a>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n       </ul>\n      </div>\n      <table class="metadata mbox-small" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000">\n       <tr>\n        <td class="mbox-image">\n         <img alt="Book icon" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" height="30" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Office-book.svg/30px-Office-book.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Office-book.svg/45px-Office-book.svg.png style="font-weight: bold">\n          <li>\n           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Book:United_States" title="Book:United States">\n            Book: United States\n           </a>\n          </li>\n         </ul>\n        </td>\n       </tr>\n      </table>\n      <ul>\n       <li>\n        <a href="/wiki/Index_of_United_States-related_articles" title="Index of United States-related articles">\n         Index of United States-related articles\n        </a>\n       </li>\n       <li>\n        <a href="/wiki/Lists_of_U.S._state_topics" title="Lists of U.S. state topics">\n         Lists of U.S. state topics\n        </a>\n       </li>\n       <li>\n        <a href="/wiki/Outline_of_the_United_States" title="Outline of the United States">\n         Outline of the United States\n        </a>\n       </li>\n      </ul>\n      <h2>\n       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">\n        Notes\n       </span>\n      </h2>\n      <div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 35em; -webkit-column-width: 35em; column-width: 35em; list-style-type: decimal;">\n       <ol class="references">\n        <li id="cite_note-2">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-2">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          <a href="/wiki/Title_36_of_the_United_States_Code" title="Title 36 of the United States Code">\n           36 U.S.C.\n          </a>\n          <a class="external text" href="https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/36/302" rel="nofollow">\n           \xc2\xa7\xc2\xa0302\n          </a>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-7">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-7">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          English is the\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Official_language_of_the_United_States" title="Official language of the United States">\n           official language\n          </a>\n          of 32 states; English and\n          <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_language" title="Hawaiian language">\n           Hawaiian\n          </a>\n          are both official languages in\n          <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">\n           Hawaii\n          </a>\n          , and English and\n          <a href="/wiki/Alaska_Native_languages" title="Alaska Native languages">\n           20 Indigenous languages\n          </a>\n          are official in\n          <a href="/wiki/Alaska" title="Alaska">\n           Alaska\n          </a>\n          .\n          <a href="/wiki/Algonquian_languages" title="Algonquian languages">\n           Algonquian\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a href="/wiki/Cherokee_language" title="Cherokee language">\n           Cherokee\n          </a>\n          , and\n          <a href="/wiki/Sioux_language" title="Sioux language">\n           Sioux\n          </a>\n          are among many other official languages in Native-controlled lands throughout the country.\n          <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">\n           French\n          </a>\n          is a\n          <i>\n           de facto\n          </i>\n          , but unofficial, language in\n          <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">\n           Maine\n          </a>\n          and\n          <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">\n           Louisiana\n          </a>\n          , while\n          <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">\n           New Mexico\n          </a>\n          law grants\n          <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">\n           Spanish\n          </a>\n          a special status.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECobarrubias1983195_5-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECobarrubias1983195-5">\n            [4]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGarc.C3.ADa2011167_6-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGarc.C3.ADa2011167-6">\n            [5]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-language-8">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-language_8-0">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          In five territories, English as well as one or more indigenous languages are official:\n          <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">\n           Spanish\n          </a>\n          in Puerto Rico,\n          <a href="/wiki/Samoan_language" title="Samoan language">\n           Samoan\n          </a>\n          in American Samoa,\n          <a href="/wiki/Chamorro_language" title="Chamorro language">\n           Chamorro\n          </a>\n          in both Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands.\n          <a href="/wiki/Carolinian_language" title="Carolinian language">\n           Carolinian\n          </a>\n          is also an official language in the Northern Mariana Islands.\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-time-17">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-time_17-0">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          See\n          <a href="/wiki/Time_in_the_United_States" title="Time in the United States">\n           Time in the United States\n          </a>\n          for details about laws governing time zones in the United States.\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-drive-18">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-drive_18-0">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          Except\n          <a href="/wiki/American_Samoa" title="American Samoa">\n           American Samoa\n          </a>\n          and the\n          <a href="/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands" title="United States Virgin Islands">\n           Virgin Islands\n          </a>\n          .\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-22">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-22">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          The five major territories are\n          <a href="/wiki/American_Samoa" title="American Samoa">\n           American Samoa\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">\n           Guam\n          </a>\n          , the\n          <a href="/wiki/Northern_Mariana_Islands" title="Northern Mariana Islands">\n           Northern Mariana Islands\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico" title="Puerto Rico">\n           Puerto Rico\n          </a>\n          , and the\n          <a href="/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands" title="United States Virgin Islands">\n           United States Virgin Islands\n          </a>\n          . There are eleven smaller island areas without permanent populations:\n          <a href="/wiki/Baker_Island" title="Baker Island">\n           Baker Island\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a href="/wiki/Howland_Island" title="Howland Island">\n           Howland Island\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a href="/wiki/Jarvis_Island" title="Jarvis Island">\n           Jarvis Island\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a href="/wiki/Johnston_Atoll" title="Johnston Atoll">\n           Johnston Atoll\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a href="/wiki/Kingman_Reef" title="Kingman Reef">\n           Kingman Reef\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a href="/wiki/Midway_Atoll" title="Midway Atoll">\n           Midway Atoll\n          </a>\n          , and\n          <a href="/wiki/Palmyra_Atoll" title="Palmyra Atoll">\n           Palmyra Atoll\n          </a>\n          . U.S. sovereignty over\n          <a href="/wiki/Bajo_Nuevo_Bank" title="Bajo Nuevo Bank">\n           Bajo Nuevo Bank\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a href="/wiki/Navassa_Island" title="Navassa Island">\n           Navassa Island\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a href="/wiki/Serranilla_Bank" title="Serranilla Bank">\n           Serranilla Bank\n          </a>\n          , and\n          <a href="/wiki/Wake_Island" title="Wake Island">\n           Wake Island\n          </a>\n          is disputed.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">\n           <a href="#cite_note-21">\n            [16]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-28">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-28">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          The\n          <i>\n           Encyclop\xc3\xa6dia Britannica\n          </i>\n          lists China as world\'s third-largest country (after Russia and Canada) with a total area of 9,572,900 sq km,\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">\n           <a href="#cite_note-24">\n            [18]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          and the United States as fourth-largest at 9,526,468 sq km. The figure for the United States is less than in the\n          <i>\n           CIA World Factbook\n          </i>\n          because it\n          <i>\n           excludes\n          </i>\n          coastal and territorial waters.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">\n           <a href="#cite_note-25">\n            [19]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n         <p>\n          <span class="reference-text">\n           The\n           <i>\n            CIA World Factbook\n           </i>\n           lists the United States as the third-largest country (after Russia and Canada) with total area of 9,833,517 sq km,\n           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">\n            <a href="#cite_note-26">\n             [20]\n            </a>\n           </sup>\n           and China as fourth-largest at 9,596,960 sq km.\n           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">\n            <a href="#cite_note-27">\n             [21]\n            </a>\n           </sup>\n           This figure for the United States is greater than in the\n           <i>\n            Encyclop\xc3\xa6dia Britannica\n           </i>\n           because it\n           <i>\n            includes\n           </i>\n           coastal and territorial waters.\n          </span>\n         </p>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-96">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-96">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          Spain sent\n          <a href="/wiki/Spanish_expeditions_to_the_Pacific_Northwest" title="Spanish expeditions to the Pacific Northwest">\n           several expeditions to Alaska\n          </a>\n          to assert its long-held claim over the Pacific Northwest which dated back to the 16th century. During the decade 1785\xe2\x80\x931795 British merchants, encouraged by\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sir_Joseph_Banks" title="Sir Joseph Banks">\n           Sir Joseph Banks\n          </a>\n          and supported by their government, made a sustained attempt to develop this trade despite Spain\'s claims and navigation rights. The endeavours of these merchants did not last long in the face of Spain\'s opposition. The challenge was also opposed by a Japan holding obdurately to national seclusion.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">\n           <a href="#cite_note-95">\n            [88]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-113">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-113">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          His previous arrival coincided with the\n          <a href="/wiki/Makahiki" title="Makahiki">\n           Makahiki\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tabrah1984_110-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-Tabrah1984-110">\n            [102]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          a festival celebrating the\n          <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_religion" title="Hawaiian religion">\n           Hawaiian deity\n          </a>\n          <a href="/wiki/Lono" title="Lono">\n           Lono\n          </a>\n          .\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sahlins1996_111-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-Sahlins1996-111">\n            [103]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          After the\n          <a href="/wiki/HMS_Resolution_(1771)" title="HMS Resolution (1771)">\n           HMS\n           <i>\n            Resolution\n           </i>\n          </a>\n          and\n          <a href="/wiki/HMS_Discovery_(1774)" title="HMS Discovery (1774)">\n           HMS\n           <i>\n            Discovery\n           </i>\n          </a>\n          had left the islands, the season for battle and war had begun under the worship and rituals for\n          <a href="/wiki/K%C5%AB" title="K\xc5\xab">\n           K\xc5\xabka\xca\xbbilimoku\n          </a>\n          , the\n          <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_religion" title="Hawaiian religion">\n           Hawaiian deity\n          </a>\n          of war.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meyer2014_112-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-Meyer2014-112">\n            [104]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-123">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-123">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          On the evening of February 13, while anchored in Kealakekua Bay after their return, one of only two long boats was stolen.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moore2012_114-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-Moore2012-114">\n            [105]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          The Hawaiians had begun to openly challenging the foreigners. In retaliation, Cook tried to take the\n          <a href="/wiki/Ali%CA%BBi" title="Ali\xca\xbbi">\n           ali\xca\xbbi nui\n          </a>\n          of the island of Hawaii,\n          <a href="/wiki/Kalani%CA%BB%C5%8Dpu%CA%BBu" title="Kalani\xca\xbb\xc5\x8dpu\xca\xbbu">\n           Kalani\xca\xbb\xc5\x8dpu\xca\xbbu\n          </a>\n          as ransom for the boats.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cook1971_115-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-Cook1971-115">\n            [106]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          The following morning of February 14, 1779\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">\n           <a href="#cite_note-116">\n            [107]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          Cook and his men went directly to Kalani\xca\xbb\xc5\x8dpu\xca\xbbu\'s enclosure where the monarch was still sleeping.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-O.27Sullivan2008_117-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-O.27Sullivan2008-117">\n            [108]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          One of ruler\'s wives,\n          <a href="/wiki/K%C4%81nekap%C5%8Dlei" title="K\xc4\x81nekap\xc5\x8dlei">\n           K\xc4\x81nekap\xc5\x8dlei\n          </a>\n          pleaded with them to stop.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chambers2006_118-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-Chambers2006-118">\n            [109]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          Cook\'s men and the Marines were confronted on the beach by thousands of\n          <a href="/wiki/Native_Hawaiians" title="Native Hawaiians">\n           Native Hawaiians\n          </a>\n          .\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bown2008_119-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-Bown2008-119">\n            [110]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          Cook tried to move the elderly man but he refused. As the townspeople began to surrounding them, Cook and his men raised their guns. Two chiefs and the monarch\'s wife shielded Kalani\xca\xbb\xc5\x8dpu\xca\xbbu as Cook tried to force him to his feet.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tregaskis1973_120-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-Tregaskis1973-120">\n            [111]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          The crowd became hostile and\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kana%CA%BBina" title="Kana\xca\xbbina">\n           Kana\xca\xbbina\n          </a>\n          (one of the monarch\'s attendants) approached Cook, who reacted by striking him with the broad side of his sword. Kana\xca\xbbina instantly grabbed Cook and lifted him off his feet.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Williams2008_121-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-Williams2008-121">\n            [112]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          Kana\xca\xbbina released Cook, who fell to the ground as another attendant, Nuaa fatally stabbed Cook to death.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Meares1791_122-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-Meares1791-122">\n            [113]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-275">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-275">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          The United States has a very diverse population; 37\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.s._ancestry" title="U.s. ancestry">\n           ancestry groups\n          </a>\n          have more than one million members.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-An2000_272-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-An2000-272">\n            [262]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_American" title="German American">\n           German Americans\n          </a>\n          are the largest ethnic group (more than 50 million) \xe2\x80\x93 followed by\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irish_American" title="Irish American">\n           Irish Americans\n          </a>\n          (circa 37 million),\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mexican_American" title="Mexican American">\n           Mexican Americans\n          </a>\n          (circa 31 million) and\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_American" title="English American">\n           English Americans\n          </a>\n          (circa 28 million).\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">\n           <a href="#cite_note-273">\n            [263]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">\n           <a href="#cite_note-274">\n            [264]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_American" title="White American">\n           White Americans\n          </a>\n          are the largest\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Race_(human_classification)" title="Race (human classification)">\n           racial group\n          </a>\n          ;\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">\n           black Americans\n          </a>\n          are the nation\'s largest\n          <a href="/wiki/Minority_group" title="Minority group">\n           racial minority\n          </a>\n          (note that in the U.S. Census,\n          <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans" title="Hispanic and Latino Americans">\n           Hispanic and Latino Americans\n          </a>\n          are counted as an\n          <i>\n           ethnic\n          </i>\n          group, not a "racial" group), and third-largest ancestry group.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-An2000_272-1">\n           <a href="#cite_note-An2000-272">\n            [262]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_American" title="Asian American">\n           Asian Americans\n          </a>\n          are the country\'s second-largest racial minority; the three largest Asian American ethnic groups are\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_American" title="Chinese American">\n           Chinese Americans\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filipino_American" title="Filipino American">\n           Filipino Americans\n          </a>\n          , and\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_American" title="Indian American">\n           Indian Americans\n          </a>\n          .\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-An2000_272-2">\n           <a href="#cite_note-An2000-272">\n            [262]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-297">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-297">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          <a href="/wiki/Fertility" title="Fertility">\n           Fertility\n          </a>\n          is also a factor; in 2010 the average Hispanic woman gave birth to 2.35 children in her lifetime, compared to 1.97 for non-Hispanic black women and 1.79 for non-Hispanic white women (both below the\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Replacement_rates" title="Replacement rates">\n           replacement rate\n          </a>\n          of 2.1).\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_292-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-292">\n            [281]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          <a href="/wiki/Minority_group" title="Minority group">\n           Minorities\n          </a>\n          (as defined by the Census Bureau as all those beside non-Hispanic, non-multiracial whites) constituted 36.3% of the population in 2010 (this is nearly 40% in 2015),\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">\n           <a href="#cite_note-293">\n            [282]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          and over 50% of children under age one,\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">\n           <a href="#cite_note-294">\n            [283]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          and are projected to constitute the majority by 2042.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">\n           <a href="#cite_note-295">\n            [284]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          This contradicts the report by the National Vital Statistics Reports, based on the U.S. census data, which concludes that 54% (2,162,406 out of 3,999,386 in 2010) of births were non-Hispanic white.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_292-1">\n           <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-292">\n            [281]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          The Hispanic birth rate plummeted 25% between 2006 and 2013 while the rate for non-Hispanics decreased just 5%.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">\n           <a href="#cite_note-296">\n            [285]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-320">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-320">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          Source: 2015\n          <a href="/wiki/American_Community_Survey" title="American Community Survey">\n           American Community Survey\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Census_Bureau" title="U.S. Census Bureau">\n           U.S. Census Bureau\n          </a>\n          . Most respondents who speak a language other than English at home also report speaking English "well" or "very well" For the language groups listed above, the strongest English-language proficiency is among speakers of German (96% report that they speak English "well" or "very well"), followed by speakers of French (93.5%), Tagalog (92.8%), Spanish (74.1%), Korean (71.5%), Chinese (70.4%), and Vietnamese (66.9%).\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-430">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-430">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          In January 2015, U.S. federal government debt held by the public was approximately $13 trillion, or about 72% of U.S. GDP. Intra-governmental holdings stood at $5 trillion, giving a combined total debt of $18.080 trillion.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated5_426-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-autogenerated5-426">\n            [413]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427">\n           <a href="#cite_note-427">\n            [414]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          By 2012, total federal debt had surpassed 100% of U.S. GDP.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428">\n           <a href="#cite_note-428">\n            [415]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          The U.S. has a\n          <a href="/wiki/Credit_rating" title="Credit rating">\n           credit rating\n          </a>\n          of AA+ from\n          <a href="/wiki/Standard_%26_Poor%27s" title="Standard &amp; Poor\'s">\n           Standard &amp; Poor\'s\n          </a>\n          , AAA from\n          <a href="/wiki/Fitch_Ratings" title="Fitch Ratings">\n           Fitch\n          </a>\n          , and AAA from\n          <a href="/wiki/Moody%27s_Investors_Service" title="Moody\'s Investors Service">\n           Moody\'s\n          </a>\n          .\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429">\n           <a href="#cite_note-429">\n            [416]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-496">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-496">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          The\n          <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">\n           Stockholm International Peace Research Institute\n          </a>\n          , SIPRI, found that the United States\'\n          <a href="/wiki/Arms_industry" title="Arms industry">\n           arms industry\n          </a>\n          was the world\'s biggest exporter of major weapons from 2005 to 2009,\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494">\n           <a href="#cite_note-494">\n            [480]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          and remained the largest exporter of major weapons during a period between 2010 and 2014, followed by Russia, China (PRC), and Germany.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495">\n           <a href="#cite_note-495">\n            [481]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-574">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-574">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          Droughts are likely to particularly affect the 66 percent of Americans whose communities depend on surface water.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA:Water_on_Tap_572-0">\n           <a href="#cite_note-EPA:Water_on_Tap-572">\n            [557]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n          As for drinking water quality, there are concerns about disinfection by-products,\n          <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">\n           lead\n          </a>\n          ,\n          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Perchlorates" title="Perchlorates">\n           perchlorates\n          </a>\n          and pharmaceutical substances, but generally\n          <a href="/wiki/Drinking_water_quality_in_the_United_States" title="Drinking water quality in the United States">\n           drinking water quality in the U.S.\n          </a>\n          is good.\n          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573">\n           <a href="#cite_note-573">\n            [558]\n           </a>\n          </sup>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n       </ol>\n      </div>\n title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Trends+in+world+military+expenditure%2C+2013&amp;rft.pub=Stockholm+International+Peace+Research+Institute&amp;rft.date=2014-04&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fbooks.sipri.org%2Fproduct_info%3Fc_product_id%3D476&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUnited+States">\n           <span style="display:none;">\n           </span>\n          </span>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-FOOTNOTEMartone2016504-46">\n         <span </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-48">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-48">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          DeLear, Byron (July 4, 2013)\n          <a class="external text" href="http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/2013/0704/Who-coined-United-States-of-America-Mystery-might-have-intriguing-answer" rel="nofollow">\n           Who coined \'United States of America\'? Mystery might have intriguing answer.\n          </a>\n          "Historians have long tried to pinpoint exactly when the name \'United States of America\' was first used and by whom... ...This latest find comes in a letter that Stephen Moylan, Esq., wrote to Col. Joseph Reed from the Continental Army Headquarters in Cambridge, Mass., during the Siege of Boston. The two men lived with Washington in Cambridge, with Reed serving as Washington\'s favorite military secretary and Moylan fulfilling the role during Reed\'s absence."\n          <i>\n           Christian Science Monitor\n          </i>\n          (Boston, MA).\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-49">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-49">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          Touba, Mariam (November 5, 2014)\n          <a class="external text" href="http://blog.nyhistory.org/coined-phrase-united-states-america-may-never-guess/" rel="nofollow">\n           Who Coined the Phrase \'United States of America\'? You May Never Guess\n          </a>\n          "Here, on January 2, 1776, seven months before the Declaration of Independence and a week before the publication of Paine\'s\n          <i>\n           Common Sense\n          </i>\n          , Stephen Moylan, an acting secretary to General George Washington, spells it out, \'I should like vastly to go with full and ample powers from the United States of America to Spain\' to seek foreign assistance for the cause."\n          <i>\n           New-York Historical Society Museum &amp; Library\n          </i>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-50">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-50">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          Fay, John (July 15, 2016)\n          <a class="external text" href="http://www.irishcentral.com/roots/history/The-forgotten-Irishman-who-named-the-United-States-of-America.html" rel="nofollow">\n           The forgotten Irishman who named the \'United States of America\'\n          </a>\n          "According to the NY Historical Society, Stephen Moylan was the man responsible for the earliest documented use of the phrase "United States of America." But who was Stephen Moylan?"\n          <i>\n           IrishCentral.com\n          </i>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-51">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-51">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          <cite class="citation journal">\n           <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141219053616/http://research.history.org/DigitalLibrary/VirginiaGazette/VGIssueThumbs.cfm?IssueIDNo=76.DH.16" rel="nofollow">\n            "\n            <span style="padding-left:0.2em;">\n             "\n            </span>\n            To the inhabitants of Virginia," by A PLANTER.\n            <i>\n             Dixon and Hunter\'s. April 6, 1776, Williamsburg, Virginia. Letter is also included in Peter Force\'s\n            </i>\n            American Archives\n            <i>\n             "\n            </i>\n           </a>\n           .\n           <b>\n            5\n           </b>\n           (1287). Women and Peace Series. New York City: Feminist Press at CUNY. p.\xc2\xa0vii.\n           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">\n            ISBN\n           </a>\n           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/1-55861-139-8" title="Special:BookSources/1-55861-139-8">\n            1-55861-139-8\n           </a>\n           .\n           <q>\n            Carrie Chapmann Catt led an army of voteless women in 1919 to pressure Congress to pass the constitutional amendment giving them the right to vote and convinced state legislatures to ratify it in 1920.\xc2\xa0... Catt was one of the best-known women in the United States in the first half of the twentieth century and was on all lists of famous American women.\n           </q>\n          </cite>\n          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Carrie+Chapman+Catt%3A+A+Public+Life&amp;rft.place=New+York+City&amp;rft.series=Women+and+Peace+Series&amp;rft.pages=vii&amp;rft.pub=Feminist+Press+at+CUNY&amp;rft.date=1996&amp;rft.isbn=1-55861-139-8&amp;rft.aulast=Voris&amp;rft.aufirst=Jacqueline+Van&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUnited+States">\n           <span style="display:none;">\n           </span>\n          </span>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-167">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-167">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          Winchester pp. 410\xe2\x80\x93411\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-168">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-168">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          <cite class="citation book">\n           Axinn, June; Stern, Mark J. Retrieved\n            <span class="nowrap">\n             August 15,\n            </span>\n            2012\n           </span>\n           .\n           <q>\n            In 1965, taxes collected by federal, state and municipal governments amounted to 24.7 percent of the nation\'s output. In 2010, they amounted to 24.8 percent. Excluding Chile and Mexico, the United States raises less tax revenue, as a share of the economy, than every other industrial country.\n           </q>\n          </cite>\n          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=America%27s+Aversion+to+Taxes&amp;rft.date=2012-08-14&amp;rft.au=Porter%2C+Eduardo&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2012%2F08%2F15%2Fbusiness%2Feconomy%2Fslipping-behind-because-of-an-aversion-to-taxes.html%3F_r%3D1%26src%3Drecg&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUnited+States">\n           <span style="display:none;">\n           </span>\n          </span>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-CBO_Historical_Tables_2012FY-405">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          ^\n          <a href="#cite_ref-CBO_Historical_Tables_2012FY_405-0">\n           <sup>\n            <i>\n             <b>\n              a\n             </b>\n            </i>\n           </sup>\n          </a>\n          <a href="#cite_ref-CBO_Historical_Tables_2012FY_405-1">\n           <sup>\n            <i>\n             <b>\n              b\n             </b>\n            </i>\n           </sup>\n          </a>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          <cite class="citation web">\n           <a class="external text" href="http://cbo.gov/publication/43904" rel="nofollow">\n            "CBO Historical Tables-February 2013"\n           </a>\n           . Retrieved\n            <span class="nowrap">\n             September 24,\n            </span>\n            2015\n           </span>\n           .\n           <q>\n            Various studies have compared the progressivity of tax systems of European countries with that of the United States (see for instance Prasad and Deng, 2009; Piketty and Saez, 2007; Joumard, 2001). Though they use different definitions, methods and databases, they reach the same conclusion: the US tax system is more progressive than those of the continental European countries.\n           </q>\n          </cite>\n          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=OECD+Journal%3A+Economic+Studies&amp;rft.atitle=Tackling+income+inequality+The+role+of+taxes+and+transfers&amp;rft.pages=27&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft.au=Isabelle+Joumard&amp;rft.au=Mauro+Pisu&amp;rft.au=Debbie+Bloch&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oecd.org%2Feco%2Fpublic-finance%2FTacklingincomeinequalityTheroleoftaxesandtransfers.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUnited+States">\n           <span style="display:none;">\n           </span>\n          </span>\n         </span>\n        </li>\n        <li id="cite_note-409">\n         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">\n          <b>\n           <a href="#cite_ref-409">\n            ^\n           </a>\n          </b>\n         </span>\n         <span class="reference-text">\n          Taxation in the US:\n         </span>\n         <ul>\n          <li>\n           <span class="reference-text">\n            <cite class="citation journal">\n             Prasad, M.; Deng, Y.
